column325: 'Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 7 to 6).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 5e to 4). Formerly recorded as "Devensian" in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column326: 26/01/1998.The chronology is based upon analogy with an Ipswichian hippo fauna in the correlative Allenton Sand and Gravel of the lower Dove.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 6). Formerly stated to be Wolstonian in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column327: 26/01/1998.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 12 or 10). Formerly stated simply to be Anglian in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column328: 26/01/1998.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 8). Formerly stated to be Wolstonian in the original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column329: 26/01/1998. The chronology is based in its position above the Eggington Common Member and below the assumed Eagle Moor Member.@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 5e to 4 or ?2). It was originally thought (Brandon and Sumbler
column330: 1988) that essentially the whole of the deposit was Ipswichian but subsequently it became clear that the temperate fossiliferous deposits were local basement remnants and that the bulk of the deposit was a cold-stage aggradation. This is probably largely MIS 4
column331: but could extend into MIS 2 (and could therefore in part correlate with the Holme Pierepont Sand and Gravel of the Trent).@en;Upper Pleistocene to Holocene (MI Stage 2 to 1).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 2). Formerly stated to be Devensian in the original Informal Lexicon entry provided by A Brandon
column332: 26/01/1998.@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 2 west of the Lincoln Gap
column333: or 5e to 2 east of the Lincoln Gap). The chronology is based on the assumption that west of the Lincoln Gap (where Scarle Sand and Gravel can be separated) it is broadly correlative with the Holme Pierrepont of the Trent
column334: whereas east of the Gap it includes everything that is Ipswichian or later
column335: thus including correlatives of the Scarle Sand and Gravel
column336: as in the Castle Sand and Gravel Member of the Bain.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 12 or 10).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage [5e to] 4). Formerly stated to be Devensian in the original Code_Only Lexicon entry provided by J Carney
column337: 28/03/2002.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 7 to 6). The chronology is based on the assumed correlation with the Balderton Sand and Gravel. Organic deposits are associated with the Southrey at at least two sites
column338: but it is not clear if they are beneath the Southrey or in earlier or later unrelated channels. This is not likely to be resolved in the near future.@en;Mid Pleistocene (??MI Stage 6).@en'
column347: 'The definition compiler notes: At Newark itself this terrace seems to be at c.18m

column353: wrongly correlated the type Beeston Sand and Gravel with the older Balderton Sand and Gravel downstream

column355: given the fact that it is cleary somewhat degraded
column356: at the right elevation to be Beeston (and too low to be Egginton Common/Balderton) and was correlated with the type Beeston by Clayton
column357: etc. In my opinion it is Beeston Sand and Gravel. However
column358: Lowe (1989) and Charsley et al. have it as a separate entity
column359: presumably because they say it passes down into
column360: and intercalates with sandy pebbly clay which they interpret as a glacial melt-out. But I suspect it more likely that these are contemporaneous head gravels etc. Currently this unit is only distinguished as such on Sheet 141 (Loughborough). It is undoubtedly present upstream
column361: but the distribution shown by Clayton (1953) would seem to be mostly Holme Pierrepont Sand and Gravel. On Sheet 126 (Nottingham) it is named the Bassingfield Sand and Gravel (see above). I would not expect it to be present significantly downstream of Newark because [in my opinion] the river followed the Proto-Trent route at the time
column362: where it is [probably] represented by the Scarle Sand and Gravel.@en;Partly because of misunderstandings about the age relationships
column364: 1999) ascribed the downstream end of the Fulbeck Sand and Gravel (which would lie on Sheet 114) as a separate Bassingham Fen Member. The latter name is superfluous and is now subsumed into the Fulbeck Sand and Gravel.@en;As defined  this is a rather unsatisfactory portmanteau term to cover all the younger sands and gravels of the Proto-Trent and Witham areas that are not otherwise named. Very little is known about these deposits so  more specific names have not yet ben applied. Younger parts include Witham gravels of local derivation and

column320: 'Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 7 to 6).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 5e to 4). Formerly recorded as "Devensian" in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column321: 26/01/1998.The chronology is based upon analogy with an Ipswichian hippo fauna in the correlative Allenton Sand and Gravel of the lower Dove.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 6). Formerly stated to be Wolstonian in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column322: 26/01/1998.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 12 or 10). Formerly stated simply to be Anglian in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column323: 26/01/1998.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 8). Formerly stated to be Wolstonian in the original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column324: 26/01/1998. The chronology is based in its position above the Eggington Common Member and below the assumed Eagle Moor Member.@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 5e to 4 or ?2). It was originally thought (Brandon and Sumbler
column325: 1988) that essentially the whole of the deposit was Ipswichian but subsequently it became clear that the temperate fossiliferous deposits were local basement remnants and that the bulk of the deposit was a cold-stage aggradation. This is probably largely MIS 4
column326: but could extend into MIS 2 (and could therefore in part correlate with the Holme Pierepont Sand and Gravel of the Trent).@en;Upper Pleistocene to Holocene (MI Stage 2 to 1).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 2). Formerly stated to be Devensian in the original Informal Lexicon entry provided by A Brandon
column327: 26/01/1998.@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 2 west of the Lincoln Gap
column328: or 5e to 2 east of the Lincoln Gap). The chronology is based on the assumption that west of the Lincoln Gap (where Scarle Sand and Gravel can be separated) it is broadly correlative with the Holme Pierrepont of the Trent
column329: whereas east of the Gap it includes everything that is Ipswichian or later
column330: thus including correlatives of the Scarle Sand and Gravel
column331: as in the Castle Sand and Gravel Member of the Bain.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 12 or 10).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage [5e to] 4). Formerly stated to be Devensian in the original Code_Only Lexicon entry provided by J Carney
column332: 28/03/2002.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 7 to 6). The chronology is based on the assumed correlation with the Balderton Sand and Gravel. Organic deposits are associated with the Southrey at at least two sites
column333: but it is not clear if they are beneath the Southrey or in earlier or later unrelated channels. This is not likely to be resolved in the near future.@en;Mid Pleistocene (??MI Stage 6).@en'
column342: 'The definition compiler notes: At Newark itself this terrace seems to be at c.18m
column343: which (depending upon how the profile is drawn) could read as only 7m above the Trent - hence previous confusion with the Beeston Terrace. However
column344: the terrace here could be degraded in some way
column345: because it is slightly higher than this "downstream". If the profile is projected back towards Newark it "ought" to be 10 or 11m above the modern floodplain.@en;Clayton
column348: wrongly correlated the type Beeston Sand and Gravel with the older Balderton Sand and Gravel downstream
column349: and also (it appears) with the younger Holme Pierrepont Sand and Gravel upstream. The Bassingfield Sand and Gravel of Sheet 126 is
column350: given the fact that it is cleary somewhat degraded
column351: at the right elevation to be Beeston (and too low to be Egginton Common/Balderton) and was correlated with the type Beeston by Clayton
column352: etc. In my opinion it is Beeston Sand and Gravel. However
column353: Lowe (1989) and Charsley et al. have it as a separate entity
column354: presumably because they say it passes down into
column355: and intercalates with sandy pebbly clay which they interpret as a glacial melt-out. But I suspect it more likely that these are contemporaneous head gravels etc. Currently this unit is only distinguished as such on Sheet 141 (Loughborough). It is undoubtedly present upstream
column356: but the distribution shown by Clayton (1953) would seem to be mostly Holme Pierrepont Sand and Gravel. On Sheet 126 (Nottingham) it is named the Bassingfield Sand and Gravel (see above). I would not expect it to be present significantly downstream of Newark because [in my opinion] the river followed the Proto-Trent route at the time
column357: where it is [probably] represented by the Scarle Sand and Gravel.@en;Partly because of misunderstandings about the age relationships
column359: 1999) ascribed the downstream end of the Fulbeck Sand and Gravel (which would lie on Sheet 114) as a separate Bassingham Fen Member. The latter name is superfluous and is now subsumed into the Fulbeck Sand and Gravel.@en;As defined  this is a rather unsatisfactory portmanteau term to cover all the younger sands and gravels of the Proto-Trent and Witham areas that are not otherwise named. Very little is known about these deposits so  more specific names have not yet ben applied. Younger parts include Witham gravels of local derivation and
column361: there are deposits that might represent southwards outflow from Lake Humber.@en'

column215: '(A) The unit is referred to here as Freeland Sand and Gravel Member though in Bowen (1999)

column218: this unit was placed in the Northern Drift Formation by Bowen
column219: 1999 (i.e. (?)Kesgrave Formation of the current scheme). However
column220: Sumbler (2001) showed that it is the oldest unit of the [Upper] Thames Valley Formation. In fact few would dispute this because
column222: this was generally accepted (e.g. Hey
column225: 1994; in fact most except Gibbard) as the correlative of the Black Park of the Middle Thames. As this is essentially an Anglian outwash terrace
column226: even then it was accepted implicitly that the Freeland postdated the truncation of the extended proto-Thames ?Northern Drift or Kesgrave River?. (C) Terrace surface is some 40m above modern (Evenlode) alluvial floodplain at the type locality
column227: diminishing somewhat upstream. (D) The upper boundary is given as ?ground surface? though head
column228: colluvium or soil deposits may intervene. (E) Apart from at the type locality
column229: recognition of this terrace is based on elevation
column230: and in some areas (notably on Sheet 236
column231: 253 and 254) the mapping is suspect. Prior to Sumbler 2001

More important is relationship with ?Moreton Drift? at the head of the Evenlode (see below). The presence of flint is critical to the interpretation - debate has arisen about whether or not it is the oldest terrace to contain ?significant? amounts of flint (Maddy et al.

column270: so recognition based on elevation is suspect in places; some mapping is dubious. Deposits mapped as ?Third terrace? are not necessarily Wolvercote. The feeble development of the terrace is rather surprising
column271: particularly if it is primarily late Anglian outwash derived from the Moreton Drift. However
column272: this all came down the Evenlode; whilst there is a fairly good flinty outwash terrace in the Upper Evenlode (Sheet 235
column273: 218) where (as the correlation is contentiousness) the name Daylesford Member is used. The Lower Evenlode valley is narrow and incised where it cuts through the Great Oolite limestones (so-called Evenlode Gorge) and perhaps was cleaned out at a later stage. (G) The identity of Terrace 3 on Sheet 218 is questionable. Most of the Evenlode Terrace 3 seems to be Daylesford Member (which may or may not equate with Wolvercote). That in the Cherwell valley may be Wolvercote

column316: 26/01/1998. The chronology is based in its position above the Eggington Common Member and below the assumed Eagle Moor Member.@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 5e to 4 or ?2). It was originally thought (Brandon and Sumbler
column317: 1988) that essentially the whole of the deposit was Ipswichian but subsequently it became clear that the temperate fossiliferous deposits were local basement remnants and that the bulk of the deposit was a cold-stage aggradation. This is probably largely MIS 4
column318: but could extend into MIS 2 (and could therefore in part correlate with the Holme Pierepont Sand and Gravel of the Trent).@en;Upper Pleistocene to Holocene (MI Stage 2 to 1).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 2). Formerly stated to be Devensian in the original Informal Lexicon entry provided by A Brandon
column319: 26/01/1998.@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 2 west of the Lincoln Gap
column320: or 5e to 2 east of the Lincoln Gap). The chronology is based on the assumption that west of the Lincoln Gap (where Scarle Sand and Gravel can be separated) it is broadly correlative with the Holme Pierrepont of the Trent
column321: whereas east of the Gap it includes everything that is Ipswichian or later
column322: thus including correlatives of the Scarle Sand and Gravel
column323: as in the Castle Sand and Gravel Member of the Bain.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 12 or 10).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage [5e to] 4). Formerly stated to be Devensian in the original Code_Only Lexicon entry provided by J Carney
column324: 28/03/2002.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 7 to 6). The chronology is based on the assumed correlation with the Balderton Sand and Gravel. Organic deposits are associated with the Southrey at at least two sites
column325: but it is not clear if they are beneath the Southrey or in earlier or later unrelated channels. This is not likely to be resolved in the near future.@en;Mid Pleistocene (??MI Stage 6).@en'

column281: so recognition based on elevation is suspect in places; some mapping is dubious. Deposits mapped as ?Third terrace? are not necessarily Wolvercote. The feeble development of the terrace is rather surprising

(G) The identity of Terrace 3 on Sheet 218 is questionable. Most of the Evenlode Terrace 3 seems to be Daylesford Member (which may or may not equate with Wolvercote). That in the Cherwell valley may be Wolvercote

column11: 'The basal contact of the Oulton Clay Member with the underlying Lowestoft Till Member is sharp
column12: and represented by an abrupt transition from clay-rich till
column16: north Norfolk. The deposit has been traced westwards inland in a series of shallow boreholes for some 400m.@en'
column20: 'The upper contact of the Oulton Clay Member with the overlying Pleasure Gardens Till Member is diffuse and represented by the interdigitation of beds of silt and clay with lenses of chalky till.@en'
column40: 'Composed of horizontally laminated pale grey sandy silts and grey clays with sporadic isolated pale grey sand lenses.@en'
column50: 'The Lowestoft Formation unconformably overlies a large range of Mesozoic
column52: Neogene and early Pleistocene bedrock formations
column53: and in eastern East Anglia also unconformably overlies the older glacigenic Happisburgh Formation (formerly Corton Formation on some maps) and the fluvial sands and gravels of the Dunwich Group. The tills within the Lowestoft Formation typically contain a significantly higher percentage of chalk than the underlying tills. The gravels in the Dunwich Group contain a significant amount of quartzose lithologies and only very minor quantities of erratics and chalk
column54: whereas the gravels in the Lowestoft Formation contain common erratics from Scotland and northern England
column55: and abundant chalk where not decalcified.@en'
column58: 'The Lowestoft Formation is overlain unconformably by deposits of the Britannia Catchments Group and in northeastern East Anglia by the Sheringham Cliffs Formation. Where the uppermost part of the Lowestoft Formation comprises sand and gravel
column59: it is not always easy to determine its upper boundary if overlain by younger sand and gravel
column60: but in general the younger sand and gravel is better sorted and chalk free.@en'
column69: 'The Lowestoft Formation forms an extensive sheet of chalky till
column70: together with outwash sands and gravels
column71: silts and clays. The till is characterised by its chalk and flint content. The carbonate content of the till matrix is about 30\%
column72: and tills within the underlying Happisburgh Formation have less than 20\%.@en'
column80: 'There is some debate as to the extent of the Lowestoft Formation. It is extensive over East Anglia having its southern limit near Romford
column81: Essex. It is probable that most of the chalky tills in central East Anglia are also part of the Lowestoft Formation. In northern East Anglia the very chalky tills commonly referred to informally as the "marly drift" were generally included within the Lowestoft Formation
column82: but recent work has indicated that these may belong to a younger glaciation. Likewise
column83: chalky tills in the south and east Midlands have commonly been linked with the Lowestoft Formation
column84: but these may also be younger. It is also uncertain how the pre-Devensian tills in Lincolnshire relate to the Lowestoft Formation.@en'
column86: 'Extremely variable. It is thickest in buried valleys where locally up to 60m may be present. Thick accumulations are also more generally present beneath much of northern Essex and south Suffolk.@en'
column94: 'Ground surface or unconformable contact with units of the Caledonia Glacigenic Group
column95: the Britannia Catchments Group or the British Coastal Deposits Group.@en'
column108: glaciolacustrine and glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern
column119: planar unconformable contact with units of the Dunwich and/or Crag groups
column121: 'The whole of Great Britain lying to the north of the Anglian glacial limit crossing southern England
column122: but mainly occuring between the Anglian and Devension glacial limits.@en'
column140: 'Restricted to the valley sides of the River Waveney and Hundred River to the west and south of Lowestoft.@en;Restricted to the southwestern flanks of the Yare and Waveney valleys and isolated deposits on the northern flanks of the Waveney valley near Somerleyton
column141: Norfolk-Suffolk border.@en;Cliff sections between Corton Woods
column143: north Norfolk. The deposit has been traced westwards inland in a series of shallow boreholes for some 400m.@en;Found in outcrops throughout the North Walsham and Cromer districts; occurs in coastal sections between Happisburgh and Overstrand
column147: 'The Aldeby Sand and Gravel Member is lithogically very variable; it is composed predominantly of sand and gravel that also contains lenses of reworked chalky till
column148: discrete beds of clay and silt
column149: reconstituted chalk and masses of sand transported and apparently derived from the Happisburgh Formation. The gravel fraction is composed predominantly of clasts of angular flint with some quartz and quartzite. In places beds of well-rounded flint and quartz gravel are present. The Member is thought to have formed during wastage of the Lowestoft ice from the adjacent higher ground.@en;The Haddiscoe Sand and Gravel Member comprises black
column150: well-rounded fine to coarse flint gravel. Within the gravel large rotated blocks of sand are preserved
column151: which are thought to have been in a frozen condition at the time of deposition.@en;Composed of horizontally laminated pale grey sandy silts and grey clays with sporadic isolated pale grey sand lenses.@en;The lower boundary of the Walcott Till Member consists of an olive grey to olive brown silt-rich matrix-supported diamicton that is largely massive in structure. It has a moderate matrix calcium carbonate content of c.36\% and contains an abundance of chalk and flint clasts.@en'
column155: most commonly overlies silt- and clay-rich chalky till (diamicton) of the Lowestoft Formation
column156: but also locally overlies well-sorted sands and gravels of the Crag Group and Happisburgh Formation.@en;The gravels overlie and cut down into silt and clay-rich chalky tills of the Lowestoft Formation. They also overlie sands of the Happisburgh Formation.@en;The basal contact of the Oulton Clay Member with the underlying Lowestoft Till Member is sharp
column157: and represented by an abrupt transition from clay-rich till
column158: to laminated silts and clays.@en;The lower boundary of the Walcott Till Member is irregular and erosional and lies upon either sandy Wroxham Crag Formation sediments or on laminated silts and clays of the Happisburgh Glacigenic Formation. Commonly these underlying sediments exhibit evidence of shearing. [See also the Stratotype information.]@en'
column160: 'Aldeby Sand And Gravel Member@en;Haddiscoe Sand And Gravel Member@en;Oulton Clay Member@en;Walcott Till Member@en'
column164: 'Thicknesses are imprecisely known but 18m was exposed at Oaklands Pit

column167: 'The Aldeby Sand and Gravel is overlain unconformably by variable Head deposits
column168: and peat and silt of the Breydon Formation

column116: and minor marine deposits are included where they are intercalated in dominantly fluvial formations.@en'

column76: or both 10 and 12. (C) The succession within the Wolston Formation is only touched upon; neither the Wolston Clay Member nor the synonymous Grounds Farm Member are mentioned. column78: which could be included in the Wolston Formation. Thus the limit in the east is fairly arbitrary

column81: but a list is included to show the areas where the Wolston Formation should encompass the glacial deposits.@en'

column160: 127.@en;Developed principally on the north bank of the Trent near the confluence with the Derwent in which the correlative Allenton Sand and Gravel is well developed. Present to a lesser extent elsewhere on Sheet 141 and 126; also thought to be present upstream on the Trent
column161: Dove and Tame but extent uncertain pending resurvey (Sheet 140
column163: ?124).@en;Occurs as outliers on north bank of Trent in type area (Sheet 141); thought to be present upstream
column164: particularly on the north bank of the Dove downstream of Uttoxeter (Sheet 140) and probably elsewhere
column165: (e.g. on the south bank of the Trent near Alrewas
column166: Sheet 154) but extent uncertain pending resurvey.@en;Newark on Trent to Lincoln Gap (British Geological Survey sheets 113
column171: Figure 1) with probable outliers upstream in the Uttoxeter-Derby area (sheets 140
column173: Trent-Derwent and Soar Valley formations) and possibly elsewhere.@en;Occurs as outliers on the north bank of the Trent in the Type Area (Sheet 141); thought to be present upstream
column174: particularly on the north bank of the Dove downstream of Uttoxeter (Sheet 140) and probably elsewhere. (e.g. on the south bank of the Trent near Alrewas
column175: Sheet 154) but the extent is uncertain pending resurvey.@en;Woolsthorpe-by-Belvoir [SK 84 34] to Auborne [SK 93 63] BGS sheets:142
column178: 114).@en;Extensively developed along much of the Trent
column179: Derwent and Soar within Sheet 141 and 142; distribution elsewhere uncertain pending resurvey or revision
column180: but probably present at least on adjoining sheets (?125
column185: where currently mapped mainly as alluvium.@en;Extensively developed along the upper and middle Trent and tributaries downstream from the Devensian ice limit (on Sheet 140) downstream
column186: and [probably] on the lower Trent to the Humber but precise extent in some areas pending resurvey.@en;Comprises the younger
column187: mainly Devensian fluvial deposits (i.e. excluding Flandrian alluvium) of the Witham catchment and of the Proto-Trent area (i.e. east of the Trent between Newark to Gainsborough). Note that adjoining the Trent the deposits could be classified mainly as Holme Pierrepont Sand and Gravel but the limits suggested above are an attempt to indicate a possible boundary line on the basis of this definition. The unit is not delineated as such on any published BGS map.@en;Distributed mainly along the southwest side of the present Witham valley from Heighington [TF 04 69] to Billinghay [TF 14 55]; less well developed on the east side of the Witham valley (where it might be represented by the Tattershall Airfield Member (see Reference Section);  distribution elsewhere uncertain; that indicated by Straw
column191: 115 and ?102 and ?128).@en;Currently only known in Type Area (on Sheet 114; see Brandon and Sumbler
column193: Fig.1): possibly remnants might occur elsewhere on BGS Sheet 113 and possibly on sheets 114 and 102.@en;Distributed along the east side of the present Witham valley from Southrey [TF 13 66] to Kirkstead [TF 19 60] (where it passes onto the Thorpe Member of the Bain). Distribution elsewhere uncertain but correlatives probably present northwest (upstream) of Southrey along the Barlings Eau or River Langworth
column194: to the Langworth area [TF 06 76 (BGS sheets 102
column197: ?128). Correlatives up the Langworth River are unlikely to be quartzite-rich and more probably are like the Thorpe Sand and Gravel of the Bain
column198: so it is questionable if they should be included as Southrey Sand and Gravel Member per se.@en;Currently only known around the Type locality but likely to be more widepsread flanking the Balderton Terrace between Newark-on-Trent and the Lincoln Gap (see Brandon and Sumbler
column206: clay or peat. [Generic description].@en;Predominantly cold-phase sands and gravels that underlie the Balderton Terrace. Orange-brown sandy gravel dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite (c.75\%) with subordinate subangular flint (c.15\%)
column208: etc. Infills a broad sinuous channel extending northeast from Newark towards the Lincoln Gap; terrace surface falls from c.20m above OD (c.10m above the Trent floodplain) to c.11m OD. Sections show intraformational and epigenetic ice wedge casts. Upper part locally includes a thin fluvio-aeolian coversand (Whisby Sand Bed
column209: pre-Ipswichian) and a  rubified paleosol (Hykeham Soil: Ipswichian). Basal part locally includes channel-filling organic silts (Thorpe on the Hill Bed)
column210: which yield a temporate flora and fauna assigned to MIS 7. Correlated with the Southrey Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation
column211: pre-diversionary River Trent east of Lincoln Gap) and Egginton Common Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation).@en;Predominantly cold-phase sands and gravels that underlie the Beeston Terrace. Orange-brown sandy gravel
column212: cryoturbated and decalcified in upper part at least
column213: and dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite (typically c.80\%) with subordinate subangular flint (c.10\%)
column214: plus minor Triassic and Upper Carboniferous sandstone
column215: Lower Carboniferous chert and silicified limestone; probably contains a moderate proportion of Lower Carboniferous limestone where fresh at depth. Forms a fairly well preserved terrace in the type area
column216: standing c.7m above the Trent alluvium in the type area. Merges into the correlative Allenton Sand and Gravel Member (Derwent Valley Formation)
column217: which includes the organic Crown Inn Beds (Ipswichian). Also correlated with the Wanlip Sand and Gravel Member (Soar Valley Formation) and the Fulbeck and ?Scarle Sand and Gravel members (Trent Valley Formation).@en;Predominantly cold-phase sands and gravels that underlie the Egginton Common Terrace. Intensely cryoturbated
column218: decalcified poorly sorted sand and gravel
column219: dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite (up to c.90\%) with subordinate subangular flint (up to c.15\%)
column220: Carboniferous chert
column222: etc.
column223: Fairly well developed and extensive terrace surface c.12-13m above the Trent/Dove floodplain in Type Area. Upper part locally includes a rubified paleosol (Hykeham Soil; Ipswichian). Correlated with the Borrowash Sand and Gravel Member (Derwent Valley Formation) and Burstall Sand and Gravel Member (Soar Valley Formation) and Balderton Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation).@en;Predominantly cold-phase sands and gravels that underlie the Eagle Moor Terrace. Dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite with subordinate subangular flint (typically 25\% in the Type Area)
column224: etc. Clayey and poorly sorted. In Type Area occurs as hill-top outliers falling from c.36m OD near Newark (c.25m above Trent floodplain) towards the Lincoln Gap
column225: being at c.+32m OD at Eagle Moor and possibly descending more rapidly to the east. Outliers upstream in the Loughborough district 30m+ above Trent floodplain. Correlated with the Martin Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation)
column226: east of the Lincoln Gap.@en;Predominantly cold-phase sands and gravels that underlie the Etwall Terrace. Intensely cryoturbated
column227: decalcified poorly sorted sand and gravel
column228: dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite (typically c.80\%) with subordinate subangular flint (up to c.20\%)
column229: Carboniferous chert
column231: etc. Fragmentary terrace surface appears to be c.20m above the Trent floodplain in the type area. The upper part locally includes a rubified palaeosol (Hykeham Soil; Ipswichian). The Member is correlated with the Ockbrook Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation) and Knighton Sand and Gravel Member (Soar Valley Formation).@en;Predominantly cold-phase sands and gravels that underlie the Fulbeck Terrace. Typically a clean
column232: well-sorted medium-grained sand with gravel that at depth is dominated by subangular and subrounded pebbles of Jurassic limestone (mainly Lias Group and Lincolnshire Limestone Formation)
column233: with a smaller proportion of other Jurassic lithologies
column234: flint
column235: "Bunter" quartz/quartzite
column236: etc
column237: derived from older drift deposits. Commonly appears dominated by "Bunter" and flint pebbles near the surface due to decalcification. Infills a shallow channel partly coinciding with the valley of the modern River Brant
column238: extending northnortheastwards from Woolsthorpe to Auborne. Terrace surface falls to c.6m OD at the northern end where the deposits are covered by Brant alluvium and probably are truncated by the deeper channel of the River Witham. Sections show cryogenic involutions and epigenetic ice wedge casts infilled with coversand. Basal part locally includes channel-filling organic silts (Little Syke Bed)
column239: which yield a temperate fauna and flora assigned to MIS 5e. Correlated with Beeston Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation)
column240: and Scarle Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation).@en;Gravels
column241: sands and loams that underlie the Hemington Terrace. Forms a terrace typically c.0.5 to 1m above the modern floodplain in the type area
column242: and often distinguishable from the latter by the presence of mediaeval ridge and furrow. Generally comprises a lower unit of planar cross-bedded (laterally accreted
column243: meandering river) gravel (up to 5m) and an upper unit of overbank silt (up to 2m); may also include organic muds in channels at the base. Gravel much as Holme Pierrepont Sand and Gravel
column244: i.e. dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite (c.80\%) with subordinate subangular flint
column245: etc.
column246: but typically less sandy and orange-brown (not pinkish).@en;Predominantly cold-phase sands and gravels that underlie the Holme Pierrepont Terrace. Generally pinkish
column247: poorly sorted and compositionally rather immature matrix-supported
column248: sandy
column249: trough-cross bedded (braided river) gravels with syndepositional ice-wedge casts. Gravel dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite (typically c.80\%)
column250: plus flint
column251: Triassic and Upper Carboniferous sandstone
column252: Lower Carboniferous cherts
column253: etc
column254: and other "exotic" lithogies. Forms a fairly well preserved terrace typically 1 to 2m above the floodplain in the upper and middle Trent
column255: with the deposits extending beneath those of the younger Hemington Terrace and the floodplain alluvium.@en;Predominantly cold-phase sands and gravels representing the youngest deposits of the Proto-Trent
column256: and the pre-Flandian deposits of the Witham. The former are typically dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite with subordinate subangular flint
column257: etc. but the latter have a greater proportion of flint and local Jurassic limestone
column258: etc. Surface c.1 to 2m above the Trent floodplain
column259: at Spalford
column260: and typically 3 to 6m below Witham floodplain level in the Type Area. West of the Lincoln Gap
column261: correlated with the Holme Pierrepont Member (Trent Valley Formation); whilst east of Lincoln Gap also includes older materials correlated with the Scarle and Fulbeck Sand and Gravel members (Trent Valley Formation) and Castle Sand and Gravel Member (Bain Valley Formation).@en;Predominantly cold-phase sands and gravels that underlie the Martin Terrace of the lower Witham valley. At surface
column262: dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite with subordinate subangular flint
column263: etc. Terrace preserved as extensive dissected remnants at c.+18m in the Type Area
column264: i.e about 16m above the Witham Floodplain there. Correlated with the Eagle Moor Sand and Gravel west of the Lincoln Gap.@en;Predominantly cold-phase sands and gravels that underlie the Scarle Terrace. Gravel dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite with subordinate subangular flint
column265: and rarer Triassic sandstone
column266: Lias limestone
column267: etc. Infills a shallow channel diverging from the Trent at Collingham and extending northnortheastwards to North Scarle where it is apparently truncated by the Kirkstead Sand and Gravel Member. Surface is c.3 to 4m above the Trent floodplain
column268: and up to c.2m above the adjoining Kirkstead/Holme Pierrepont Terrace. Correlated with Beeston Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation)
column269: and Fulbeck Sand and Gravel Member (Proto-Trent).@en;Predominantly cold-phase sands and gravels that underlie the Southrey Terrace. At surface
column270: dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite (c.60\%) with subordinate subangular flint
column271: etc. (c.40\%). Terrace surface highly dissected but rises to c.6 to 7m above the Witham floodplain in the Type Area. Associated silts yielding a temperate flora and fauna occur at at least two sites; these might occur at the base of the unit but relationships are uncertain. Correlated with the Balderton Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation
column272: west of the Lincoln Gap) and the Egginton Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation).@en;Reddened sands and gravels dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite with subordinate subangular flint. Underlies possible terrace remnants adjacent to the outcrop of the Balderton Sand and Gravel and with a terrace surface standing typically c.4 to 5m above the Balderton Terrace. Upper part locally includes a thin fluvio-aeolian coversand (Whisby Sand Bed
column273: pre-Ipswichian) and rubified palaeosol (Hykeham Soil; Ipswichian). Tentatively correlated with the Etwall Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation).@en'

The fluvial gravels occupy terrace levels and formations and members are defined on the basis of altitude and pebble clast content. The members comprise bodies of cross-bedded and massive
column190: moderately sorted sand and gravel. The aggradations are generally entrenched into bedrock with a difference in surface elevation of at least 5m. The upper part of the gravels which dominate the subgroup are commonly affected by pedogenesis. The Valley Farm Soil is a rubified and clay-enriched horizon affecting the top 1.0-1.5m and indicating warm interglacial conditions. The Barham Arctic Structure Soil is a complex pedogenic horizon affecting the topmost 1.0-1.5m of the subgroup and of the Valley Farm Soil (Rose and Allen 1976

The fluvial gravels occupy terrace levels and formations and members are defined on the basis of altitude and pebble clast content. The members comprise bodies of cross-bedded and massive
column183: moderately sorted sand and gravel. The aggradations are generally entrenched into bedrock with a difference in surface elevation of at least 5m. The upper part of the gravels which dominate the subgroup are commonly affected by pedogenesis. The Valley Farm Soil is a rubified and clay-enriched horizon affecting the top 1.0-1.5m and indicating warm interglacial conditions. The Barham Arctic Structure Soil is a complex pedogenic horizon affecting the topmost 1.0-1.5m of the subgroup and of the Valley Farm Soil (Rose and Allen 1976

column272: dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite (c.60\%) with subordinate subangular flint
column273: etc. (c.40\%). Terrace surface highly dissected but rises to c.6 to 7m above the Witham floodplain in the Type Area. Associated silts yielding a temperate flora and fauna occur at at least two sites; these might occur at the base of the unit but relationships are uncertain. Correlated with the Balderton Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation
column274: west of the Lincoln Gap) and the Egginton Sand and Gravel Member (Trent Valley Formation).@en;Reddened sands and gravels dominated by rounded pebbles of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite with subordinate subangular flint. Underlies possible terrace remnants adjacent to the outcrop of the Balderton Sand and Gravel and with a terrace surface standing typically c.4 to 5m above the Balderton Terrace. column326: 'Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 7 to 6).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 5e to 4). Formerly recorded as "Devensian" in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column327: 26/01/1998.The chronology is based upon analogy with an Ipswichian hippo fauna in the correlative Allenton Sand and Gravel of the lower Dove.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 6). Formerly stated to be Wolstonian in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column328: 26/01/1998.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 12 or 10). Formerly stated simply to be Anglian in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column329: 26/01/1998.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 8). Formerly stated to be Wolstonian in the original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column330: 26/01/1998. The chronology is based in its position above the Eggington Common Member and below the assumed Eagle Moor Member.@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 5e to 4 or ?2). It was originally thought (Brandon and Sumbler
column331: 1988) that essentially the whole of the deposit was Ipswichian but subsequently it became clear that the temperate fossiliferous deposits were local basement remnants and that the bulk of the deposit was a cold-stage aggradation. This is probably largely MIS 4
column332: but could extend into MIS 2 (and could therefore in part correlate with the Holme Pierepont Sand and Gravel of the Trent).@en;Upper Pleistocene to Holocene (MI Stage 2 to 1).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 2). Formerly stated to be Devensian in the original Informal Lexicon entry provided by A Brandon
column333: 26/01/1998.@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 2 west of the Lincoln Gap
column334: or 5e to 2 east of the Lincoln Gap). The chronology is based on the assumption that west of the Lincoln Gap (where Scarle Sand and Gravel can be separated) it is broadly correlative with the Holme Pierrepont of the Trent
column335: whereas east of the Gap it includes everything that is Ipswichian or later
column336: thus including correlatives of the Scarle Sand and Gravel
column337: as in the Castle Sand and Gravel Member of the Bain.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 12 or 10).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage [5e to] 4). Formerly stated to be Devensian in the original Code_Only Lexicon entry provided by J Carney
column338: 28/03/2002.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 7 to 6). The chronology is based on the assumed correlation with the Balderton Sand and Gravel. Organic deposits are associated with the Southrey at at least two sites
column339: but it is not clear if they are beneath the Southrey or in earlier or later unrelated channels. This is not likely to be resolved in the near future.@en;Mid Pleistocene (??MI Stage 6).@en'
column348: 'The definition compiler notes: At Newark itself this terrace seems to be at c.18m
column349: which (depending upon how the profile is drawn) could read as only 7m above the Trent - hence previous confusion with the Beeston Terrace. However
column350: the terrace here could be degraded in some way
column351: because it is slightly higher than this "downstream". If the profile is projected back towards Newark it "ought" to be 10 or 11m above the modern floodplain.@en;Clayton
column354: wrongly correlated the type Beeston Sand and Gravel with the older Balderton Sand and Gravel downstream
column355: and also (it appears) with the younger Holme Pierrepont Sand and Gravel upstream. The Bassingfield Sand and Gravel of Sheet 126 is
column356: given the fact that it is cleary somewhat degraded
column357: at the right elevation to be Beeston (and too low to be Egginton Common/Balderton) and was correlated with the type Beeston by Clayton
column358: etc. In my opinion it is Beeston Sand and Gravel. However
column359: Lowe (1989) and Charsley et al. have it as a separate entity
column360: presumably because they say it passes down into
column361: and intercalates with sandy pebbly clay which they interpret as a glacial melt-out. But I suspect it more likely that these are contemporaneous head gravels etc. Currently this unit is only distinguished as such on Sheet 141 (Loughborough). It is undoubtedly present upstream
column362: but the distribution shown by Clayton (1953) would seem to be mostly Holme Pierrepont Sand and Gravel. On Sheet 126 (Nottingham) it is named the Bassingfield Sand and Gravel (see above). I would not expect it to be present significantly downstream of Newark because [in my opinion] the river followed the Proto-Trent route at the time
column363: where it is [probably] represented by the Scarle Sand and Gravel.@en;Partly because of misunderstandings about the age relationships
column365: 1999) ascribed the downstream end of the Fulbeck Sand and Gravel (which would lie on Sheet 114) as a separate Bassingham Fen Member. The latter name is superfluous and is now subsumed into the Fulbeck Sand and Gravel.@en;As defined  this is a rather unsatisfactory portmanteau term to cover all the younger sands and gravels of the Proto-Trent and Witham areas that are not otherwise named. Very little is known about these deposits so  more specific names have not yet ben applied. Younger parts include Witham gravels of local derivation and
column367: there are deposits that might represent southwards outflow from Lake Humber.@en'

column145: to the clay-silt dominated lithology of the till.@en;The Ringstead Sand and Gravel Member rests unconformably on the Holkham Till Member and a variety of Cretaceous formations. column188: 'The Bacton Green Till Member exhibits a gradational lower boundary with either the Mundesley Sand Member (outwash sands) or the Runton Till Member (subglacial till) of the Sheringham Cliffs Formation.@en;Rests unconformably on earlier Middle Pleistocene strata. Rests upon Lowestoft Formation at Lower Street [TG 16 34] and Alby Hill [TG 19 34]. Rests upon Corton Sand at Suffield [TG 23 31] and Buxton [TG 21 23]. Rests upon Happisburgh Till at Erpingham [TG 18 30]. West of Erpingham may cut through the Happisburgh Till to rest upon Wroxham Crag Formation.@en;Abrupt but conformable lower boundary with either the diamicton facies of the Walcott Till Member or the sandy facies of the Mundesley Sand Member.@en;Erosional lower contact with the chalky diamicton of the Walcott Till Member. The upper surface of the latter is slightly undulatory in form with the topographic lows filled by chalk-rich gravel before passing up into the silty sands of the Mundesley Sand Member.@en;The Runton Cliffs Sand and Gravel Member rests upon the upper surface of the Bacton Green Till Member. The contact is abrupt and scoured and marked by a lithological change from till to sand and gravel. An additional geometric complexity is that the deposit has been loaded (gravitationally) into the Bacton Green Till Member.@en;The Runton Till Member rests unconformably upon preglacial marine deposits of the Wroxham Crag Formation. The boundary is sharp and planar and in places resembles a surface of decollement. The boundary is represented by a lithological change from sands and gravels to diamicton.@en;The lower boundary of the chalky diamicton facies of the Weybourne Town Till Member rests upon either the Wroxham Crag Formation or the Bacton Green Till Member. The gravel fraction is composed predominantly of clasts of angular flint with some quartz and quartzite. In places beds of well-rounded flint and quartz gravel are present. The Member is thought to have formed during wastage of the Lowestoft ice from the adjacent higher ground.@en'
column54: 'The Lowestoft Formation unconformably overlies a large range of Mesozoic
column56: Neogene and early Pleistocene bedrock formations
column57: and in eastern East Anglia also unconformably overlies the older glacigenic Happisburgh Formation (formerly Corton Formation on some maps) and the fluvial sands and gravels of the Dunwich Group. The tills within the Lowestoft Formation typically contain a significantly higher percentage of chalk than the underlying tills. The gravels in the Dunwich Group contain a significant amount of quartzose lithologies and only very minor quantities of erratics and chalk
column58: whereas the gravels in the Lowestoft Formation contain common erratics from Scotland and northern England
column59: and abundant chalk where not decalcified.@en'
column62: 'The Lowestoft Formation is overlain unconformably by deposits of the Britannia Catchments Group and in northeastern East Anglia by the Sheringham Cliffs Formation. Where the uppermost part of the Lowestoft Formation comprises sand and gravel
column63: it is not always easy to determine its upper boundary if overlain by younger sand and gravel
column64: but in general the younger sand and gravel is better sorted and chalk free.@en'
column73: 'The Lowestoft Formation forms an extensive sheet of chalky till
column74: together with outwash sands and gravels
column75: silts and clays. The till is characterised by its chalk and flint content. The carbonate content of the till matrix is about 30\%
column76: and tills within the underlying Happisburgh Formation have less than 20\%.@en'
column84: 'There is some debate as to the extent of the Lowestoft Formation. It is extensive over East Anglia having its southern limit near Romford
column85: Essex. It is probable that most of the chalky tills in central East Anglia are also part of the Lowestoft Formation. In northern East Anglia the very chalky tills commonly referred to informally as the "marly drift" were generally included within the Lowestoft Formation
column86: but recent work has indicated that these may belong to a younger glaciation. Likewise
column87: chalky tills in the south and east Midlands have commonly been linked with the Lowestoft Formation
column88: but these may also be younger. It is also uncertain how the pre-Devensian tills in Lincolnshire relate to the Lowestoft Formation.@en'
column90: 'Extremely variable. It is thickest in buried valleys where locally up to 60m may be present. Thick accumulations are also more generally present beneath much of northern Essex and south Suffolk.@en'

column138: 'The Holkham Till Member is unconformably on older deposits. Locally it overlies gravel of an Ipswichian raised beach in the Hunstanton and Morston areas. column139: to the clay-silt dominated lithology of the till.@en;The Ringstead Sand and Gravel Member rests unconformably on the Holkham Till Member and a variety of Cretaceous formations. Dominantly clast supported with a medium to coarse quartzose sand matrix. Clasts are subrounded and rounded and composed mainly of quartzite (probably reworked from Devonian conglomerates) with sparse metasedimentary rock
column152: granites and grey/black ?Mesozoic mudstones. Red sandstone clasts are present in the lowest part of the formation where it directly overlies Devonian red sandstone bedrock. The gravels are crudely horizontally bedded and interbeds of sand show both horizontal stratification and local planar cross bedding. Both gravels and sands display locally strong staining and cementation by Fe and Mn. Palaeocurrent measurements from cross beds and imbricate clasts is towards the south. Common medium beds of yellowish brown gravelly silty sandy diamicton are present and are interpreted as debris flow deposits. The upper 1 to 2m of the deposit display crude involutions and erected clast fabric indicating disruption by periglacial soil processes. Interpreted as glaciofluvial outwash and debris flow deposits.@en;A very dark to dark grey clayey

column322: 'Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 7 to 6).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 5e to 4). Formerly recorded as "Devensian" in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column323: 26/01/1998.The chronology is based upon analogy with an Ipswichian hippo fauna in the correlative Allenton Sand and Gravel of the lower Dove.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 6). Formerly stated to be Wolstonian in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column324: 26/01/1998.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 12 or 10). Formerly stated simply to be Anglian in original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column325: 26/01/1998.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 8). Formerly stated to be Wolstonian in the original Informal Lexicon entry by A Brandon
column326: 26/01/1998. The chronology is based in its position above the Eggington Common Member and below the assumed Eagle Moor Member.@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 5e to 4 or ?2). It was originally thought (Brandon and Sumbler
column327: 1988) that essentially the whole of the deposit was Ipswichian but subsequently it became clear that the temperate fossiliferous deposits were local basement remnants and that the bulk of the deposit was a cold-stage aggradation. This is probably largely MIS 4
column328: but could extend into MIS 2 (and could therefore in part correlate with the Holme Pierepont Sand and Gravel of the Trent).@en;Upper Pleistocene to Holocene (MI Stage 2 to 1).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 2). Formerly stated to be Devensian in the original Informal Lexicon entry provided by A Brandon
column329: 26/01/1998.@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage 2 west of the Lincoln Gap
column330: or 5e to 2 east of the Lincoln Gap). The chronology is based on the assumption that west of the Lincoln Gap (where Scarle Sand and Gravel can be separated) it is broadly correlative with the Holme Pierrepont of the Trent
column331: whereas east of the Gap it includes everything that is Ipswichian or later
column332: thus including correlatives of the Scarle Sand and Gravel
column333: as in the Castle Sand and Gravel Member of the Bain.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 12 or 10).@en;Upper Pleistocene (MI Stage [5e to] 4). Formerly stated to be Devensian in the original Code_Only Lexicon entry provided by J Carney
column334: 28/03/2002.@en;Middle Pleistocene (MI Stage 7 to 6). The chronology is based on the assumed correlation with the Balderton Sand and Gravel. Organic deposits are associated with the Southrey at at least two sites
column335: but it is not clear if they are beneath the Southrey or in earlier or later unrelated channels. This is not likely to be resolved in the near future.@en;Mid Pleistocene (??MI Stage 6).@en'
column344: 'The definition compiler notes: At Newark itself this terrace seems to be at c.18m
column345: which (depending upon how the profile is drawn) could read as only 7m above the Trent - hence previous confusion with the Beeston Terrace. However
column346: the terrace here could be degraded in some way

column350: wrongly correlated the type Beeston Sand and Gravel with the older Balderton Sand and Gravel downstream
column351: and also (it appears) with the younger Holme Pierrepont Sand and Gravel upstream. The Bassingfield Sand and Gravel of Sheet 126 is
column352: given the fact that it is cleary somewhat degraded
column353: at the right elevation to be Beeston (and too low to be Egginton Common/Balderton) and was correlated with the type Beeston by Clayton
column354: etc. In my opinion it is Beeston Sand and Gravel. However
column355: Lowe (1989) and Charsley et al. have it as a separate entity
column356: presumably because they say it passes down into
column357: and intercalates with sandy pebbly clay which they interpret as a glacial melt-out. But I suspect it more likely that these are contemporaneous head gravels etc. Currently this unit is only distinguished as such on Sheet 141 (Loughborough). It is undoubtedly present upstream
column358: but the distribution shown by Clayton (1953) would seem to be mostly Holme Pierrepont Sand and Gravel. On Sheet 126 (Nottingham) it is named the Bassingfield Sand and Gravel (see above). I would not expect it to be present significantly downstream of Newark because [in my opinion] the river followed the Proto-Trent route at the time
column359: where it is [probably] represented by the Scarle Sand and Gravel.@en;Partly because of misunderstandings about the age relationships
column361: 1999) ascribed the downstream end of the Fulbeck Sand and Gravel (which would lie on Sheet 114) as a separate Bassingham Fen Member. The latter name is superfluous and is now subsumed into the Fulbeck Sand and Gravel.@en;As defined  this is a rather unsatisfactory portmanteau term to cover all the younger sands and gravels of the Proto-Trent and Witham areas that are not otherwise named. Very little is known about these deposits so  more specific names have not yet ben applied. Younger parts include Witham gravels of local derivation and
column363: there are deposits that might represent southwards outflow from Lake Humber.@en'

column42: with subordinate quartz and quartzite. The gravels tend to be strongly imbricated in coastal sections. Inland there are few exposures and they comprise pebbly
column54: 'The lower boundary of the formation is erosional

column58: 'The Briton's Lane Formation forms the uppermost stratigraphical units in northern Norfolk. However

column68: 'The Briton's Lane Formation consists of several coarse-grained sand and gravel outwash lithofacies that truncate and drape pre-existing sediments in the Cromer and Mundesley districts. No in-situ till deposits have been identified to date
column69: but thrust slabs of till have been recognised at several localities.@en'
column77: 'The Briton's Lane Formation crops-out across much of northern Norfolk
column78: from Trimingham in the east to Edgefield and Holt in central north Norfolk.@en'
column80: 'Maximum thickness of the formation is estimated to be in the region of 50m.@en'
column88: 'Ground surface or unconformable contact with units of the Caledonia Glacigenic Group
column89: the Britannia Catchments Group or the British Coastal Deposits Group.@en'
column102: glaciolacustrine and glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern
column113: planar unconformable contact with units of the Dunwich and/or Crag groups

column136: and adjacent elevated ground inland between the coast and Gimingham.@en;Restricted to the area of northern Lowestoft
column137: East Anglia.@en;Coastal sections between Paston and Sidestrand.@en;Limited to the area around Tottenhill
column138: Norfolk.@en;The Briton's Lane Sand and Gravel Member is the most extensive part of the Brition's Lane Formation and forms the elevated sections of the Cromer Ridge between the Glavern Valley
column140: north Norfolk. The member also forms some of the large sand and gravel outliers between West Runton and Weybourne and has been traced southwards inland for approximately 10km.@en'
column143: 'The Beacon Hill Sand and Gravel Member consists of shelly
column144: cross-bedded and rippled sands with flint-rich gravel seams and sporadic intraformational ice wedge casts and drop-soil structures (periglacial involutions). The lower horizons of the deposits are intensely glaciotectonized.@en;The Corton Woods Sand and Gravel Member is composed of medium gravels and fine- to coarse-grained sands. The gravels comprise mainly flint
column145: with subordinate quartz and quartzite. The gravels tend to be strongly imbricated in coastal sections. Inland there are few exposures and they comprise pebbly
column147: medium-grained sands.@en;The Member consists of beds of matrix-supported gravel separated by thick beds of horizontally bedded sand. Up to 92\% of the clast content is flint
column148: with a small (c.6\%) subsidiary quartzose content.@en;The Tottenhill Sand and Gravel Member is a complex sequence of sands and gravels
column149: dominated by flint. They were formerly well exposed in the Tottenhill Gravel Pit
column150: where two units were evident. A lower unit up to 5m thick consists of medium to coarse
column152: mostly angular gravels with cross-bedding dipping steeply (20 to 25 degrees) to the southeast
column153: and with frost wedge and cryoturbation structures. The gravels contain numerous pebbles of woody and reedy peat
column155: varved clay and Jurassic and Lower Cretaceous erratics. The upper unit is about 3.5m thick and consists of fine- and medium-grained gravels
column156: which are better sorted than the lower gravels
column157: and have a planar cross-bedding dipping westwards at 8 to 15 degrees. The junction of the two units is marked by a well-defined
column158: slightly uneven surface along which the upper gravels truncate cryturbation and bedding structures in the lower gravel. The lower unit has no known outcrop.@en;The Briton's Land Sand and Gravel Member consists of horizontal
column159: massive and low angle planar cross-bedded gravels and cobble gravels with thin seams of horizontal and rippled sand. The lithology has a distinctive high flint content (c.85-89\%) of which the majority is of non-chatter marked variety (c.78-85\%). The gravels also contain a wide range of far-travelled crystalline erratics including rocks of British and Scandinavian provenance.@en'
column162: 'The lower boundary of Beacon Hill Sand and Gravel is erosional throughout much of the deposit's distribution area and it generally rests upon the Beacon Green Till Member of the Sheringham Cliffs Formation. In places
column163: especially in the vicinity of Trimingham and Gimingham
column164: the lower boundary is tectonic and wedges of Bacton Green Till have been thrust upwards into the deposit.@en;The Corton Woods Sand and Gravel Member rests unconformably on the pebbly silt and clay of the Pleasure Gardens Till Member (of the Lowestoft Formation)
column165: but also locally in cliff sections at [TM 5464 9660] a layer of black clayey silt up to 0.4m thick intervenes. The Member may also overlie the sands of the Corton Formation; where this occurs
column166: the base is marked by the incoming of gravel.@en;The Stow Hill Sand and Gravel Member rests unconformably on the upper surface of the Bacton Green Till Member between Bacton Green [TG338345] and Mundesley [TG319361]
column167: and on the Weybourne Town Till Member within large
column168: tectonically-controlled synclines between Trimingham [TG279389] and Sidestrand [TG265397].@en;The Tottenhill Sand and Gravel Member unconformably overlies silts and clays of the Nar Valley Clay and the Nar Valley Freshwater Beds with a sharp lithological change. Elsewhere it locally overlies chalky till of uncertain affinity (but probably Lowestoft Formation or Sheringham Cliffs Formation).@en;The lower boundary is generally well defined with sands and gravels resting upon an erosion surface that cuts down into and draped over tills of the Sheringham Cliffs Formation.@en'

column79: '(A) The name may need changing if it is decided that the Upper Severn should be excluded. Obviously Lower Severn would seem appropriate. The Upper Severn is entirely within the Devensian limit - in pre-Devensian times it was probably a tributary of the Dee.This is a common problem with rivers that have had major diversions during the Pleistocene e.g. Thames and Trent. (B) The list of members relates to the ?lower Severn? below Bridgnorth but even there might not be fully comprehensive if ?awkward? rivers like the Teme (see below) are included. (C) It is impractical to give a fully comprehensive definition of the base in lithological terms. (D) The Upper Boundary might need modification if head etc is not included in this type of Formation. (E) Thickness estimates are subject to possible modification. (F) Listed 50K sheets are those that include a portion of the entire Severn catchment. More work might be needed to decide if some rivers like the Teme (the valley of which includes pre-Devensian terraces related to the River Wye!)
column80: or indeed the Upper (later Devensian) Severn (see above) should be included.@en'

column82: or both 10 and 12. (C) The succession within the Wolston Formation is only touched upon; neither the Wolston Clay Member nor the synonymous Grounds Farm Member are mentioned. (D) The precise limits of the Wolston Formation are contentious. It could be taken to the Devensian limit in Lincolnshire but Lewis (in Bowen
column83: 1999) excluded things such as the Wragby Till (putting it in the Lowestoft Formation)
column84: which could be included in the Wolston Formation. Thus the limit in the east is fairly arbitrary
column85: and the northern limit is particularly vague
column86: and probably best left as such until some primary work has been done on the older drifts of the south Pennines area. (E) As this unit is not actually distinguished on any BGS maps (locally its component members are) the listing of 50K sheets is actually superfluous
column87: but a list is included to show the areas where the Wolston Formation should encompass the glacial deposits.@en'

column194: and by felsic volcanic rocks from northern Wales. The presence of mega-erratics and glacially-fractured sand grains indicate glacial erosion in the headwater regions of the river. The fluvial gravels occupy terrace levels and formations and members are defined on the basis of altitude and pebble clast content. The members comprise bodies of cross-bedded and massive
column195: moderately sorted sand and gravel. The aggradations are generally entrenched into bedrock with a difference in surface elevation of at least 5m. The upper part of the gravels which dominate the subgroup are commonly affected by pedogenesis. The Valley Farm Soil is a rubified and clay-enriched horizon affecting the top 1.0-1.5m and indicating warm interglacial conditions. The Barham Arctic Structure Soil is a complex pedogenic horizon affecting the topmost 1.0-1.5m of the subgroup and of the Valley Farm Soil (Rose and Allen 1976
column196: Rose et al 1985).@en;The formation encompasses the fluvial

column61: 'Comprises the pre-Devensian glacial succession of much of the English Midlands. Predominantly tills
column63: gravels and laminated clays. In type area and elsewhere constitutes a succession including a basal reddish-brown Trias-rich till of essentially northern provenance (Thrussington Till Member)
column64: glacialacustrine muds ([Wolston or Grounds Farm Member and] Bosworth Clay Member)
column66: chalky till with Jurassic and Cretaceous material
column67: essentially of northeastern provenance (Oadby Till Member)
column68: and flint-rich outwash gravels (Dunsmore Gravel Member). Characteristically lacks Scottish and Lake districts erratics (which characterise the Devensian Stockport Formation)
column70: etc.) erratics (which are found in the probably equivalent Nurseries and Ridgacre formations to the west of the Wolston Formation).@en'
column72: '(A) The name follows Bowen et al (1999) and BGS provisional Framework document. (B) The consensus view in academia is that this unit is Stage 12 (as per Bowen 1999)
column73: but there is evidence to suggest it is younger Stage 10
column74: or both 10 and 12. (C) The succession within the Wolston Formation is only touched upon; neither the Wolston Clay Member nor the synonymous Grounds Farm Member are mentioned. (D) The precise limits of the Wolston Formation are contentious. It could be taken to the Devensian limit in Lincolnshire but Lewis (in Bowen
column75: 1999) excluded things such as the Wragby Till (putting it in the Lowestoft Formation)
column76: which could be included in the Wolston Formation. Thus the limit in the east is fairly arbitrary
column77: and the northern limit is particularly vague
column78: and probably best left as such until some primary work has been done on the older drifts of the south Pennines area. (E) As this unit is not actually distinguished on any BGS maps (locally its component members are) the listing of 50K sheets is actually superfluous
column79: but a list is included to show the areas where the Wolston Formation should encompass the glacial deposits.@en'

column386: based on the presence of Irish Sea Ice derived shell fragmants it is here placed in the Lleyn Formation.@en'

column221: 1999 (i.e. (?)Kesgrave Formation of the current scheme). However
column222: Sumbler (2001) showed that it is the oldest unit of the [Upper] Thames Valley Formation. In fact few would dispute this because
column225: 1986; Whiteman
column226: 1992; Bridgland
column227: 1994; in fact most except Gibbard) as the correlative of the Black Park of the Middle Thames. As this is essentially an Anglian outwash terrace

column229: diminishing somewhat upstream. (D) The upper boundary is given as ?ground surface? though head

column235: 218) were included in ?Moreton Drift? and there is indeed a component of glaciofluvial outwash there.@en;Compiler?s Notes: (A) Unit named the Hanborough Gravel Member though in Bowen 1989 and in the former BGS list of computer codes it is Hanborough Member. Note that most other "terrace" units are described as "Sand and Gravel" members. (B) Parent was originally Upper Thames Valley Formation. Despite correlation problems at Goring
column236: the change is acceptable as member names in the Upper Thames remain discrete. (C) Terrace surface some 30m above modern (Evenlode) alluvial floodplain at the type locality
column237: and (apparently) an approximately similar height elsewhere. (D) The upper boundary is given as ?ground surface? though there may be head
column238: colluvium or soil deposits intervening. (E) Apart from at the type locality the recognition of this terrace is based on elevation. Mapping in some areas may be suspect so not all Fourth Terrace is necessarily the Hanborough. In the Upper Evenlode (Sheets 235
column239: 218) there are limestone gravels that probably include equivalents but this has a different name (Spelsbury Member) because it is probably a composite deposit including younger materials. There is a reasonable Hanborough Member on the Cherwell (128) Sheet
column240: however. There is no truth in the claim (Tomlinson
column241: 1929; Arkell
column242: 1947) that it equates with the Paxford Gravel of the Moreton-in-Marsh area

column244: and in previous BGS use

column246: I am happy with this as the member names in the Upper Thames remain discrete. (C)Terrace surface is up to 3m above modern alluvial floodplain
column247: with Northmoor deposits of at least two phases (MIS 5?a and Late Glacial MIS 2). Locally

column251: as the gravels extend beneath the alluvium
column252: but in this case it is probably wrong). (F) There do not appear to be equivalents on the Upper Evenlode (Sheets 218

column254: though simply Summertown-Radley Member in Bowen 1999 and in the previous BGS list of computer codes. (B) Parent was originally Upper Thames Valley Formation. Despite correlation problems at Goring
column255: this is OK as the member names in the Upper Thames remain discrete. (C) Terrace surface some 8m above modern alluvial floodplain at the type locality and (apparently) elsewhere. Locally extends below the level of the Northmoor Terrace. Includes the Stanton Harcourt Bed (organic muds
column256: MIS 7) and the Eynsham Beds (fossiliferous gravel
column257: MIS5e). Locally

column259: these do not necessarily relate to the two phases of aggradation suggested by the organic beds. (D) Upper boundary is given as ?ground surface? though head
column260: colluvium or soil deposits might intervene. (D) A different type locality (Summertown) to that specified in Bowen

column264: 235) and in the Upper Windrush (also on Sheet 235) a different name (Sherborne Member) is used because of the lack of positive correlation. The name is (probably) applicable in the Cherwell valley on Sheet 218.@en;(A) Here named Wolvercote Sand and Gravel though in Bowen (1999) and in the previous BGS list of computer codes it is Wolvercote Member. (B) Parent was formerly Upper Thames Valley Formation. Despite correlation issues at Goring
column265: revision is acceptable as member names in the Upper Thames remain discrete. (C) Terrace surface c.12m above modern alluvial floodplain at type locality
column266: and (apparently) elsewhere. At type locality
column267: Wolvercote Channel Beds (temperature fauna
column268: ?MIS 9) probably underlie the gravels (ie
column269: older) but may be within them (contemporaneous) or incised into them (younger). (D) Dating depends only partly on Wolvercote Channel. More important is relationship with ?Moreton Drift? at the head of the Evenlode (see below). The presence of flint is critical to the interpretation - debate has arisen about whether or not it is the oldest terrace to contain ?significant? amounts of flint (Maddy et al.
column270: 1991). (E) Upper Boundary given as ?ground surface? but head
column271: colluvium or soil may intervene. (F) Terrace is weakly developed and poorly defined
column272: so recognition based on elevation is suspect in places; some mapping is dubious. Deposits mapped as ?Third terrace? are not necessarily Wolvercote. The feeble development of the terrace is rather surprising
column273: particularly if it is primarily late Anglian outwash derived from the Moreton Drift. However
column274: this all came down the Evenlode; whilst there is a fairly good flinty outwash terrace in the Upper Evenlode (Sheet 235
column275: 218) where (as the correlation is contentiousness) the name Daylesford Member is used. The Lower Evenlode valley is narrow and incised where it cuts through the Great Oolite limestones (so-called Evenlode Gorge) and perhaps was cleaned out at a later stage. (G) The identity of Terrace 3 on Sheet 218 is questionable. Most of the Evenlode Terrace 3 seems to be Daylesford Member (which may or may not equate with Wolvercote). That in the Cherwell valley may be Wolvercote
column276: but mapping is suspect.@en'

column153: red sandstone and chalk. The unit locally includes rafts of red clayey diamicton and black fossiliferous mudstone. Commonly including a lower unit that is dark reddish brown.@en;Gravel with subsidiary beds of diamicton and sand. Typically brown/dark brown and olive grey. Dominantly clast supported with a medium to coarse quartzose sand matrix. Clasts are subrounded and rounded and composed mainly of quartzite (probably reworked from Devonian conglomerates) with sparse metasedimentary rock
column154: granites and grey/black ?Mesozoic mudstones. Red sandstone clasts are present in the lowest part of the formation where it directly overlies Devonian red sandstone bedrock. The gravels are crudely horizontally bedded and interbeds of sand show both horizontal stratification and local planar cross bedding. Both gravels and sands display locally strong staining and cementation by Fe and Mn. Palaeocurrent measurements from cross beds and imbricate clasts is towards the south. Common medium beds of yellowish brown gravelly silty sandy diamicton are present and are interpreted as debris flow deposits. The upper 1 to 2m of the deposit display crude involutions and erected clast fabric indicating disruption by periglacial soil processes. Interpreted as glaciofluvial outwash and debris flow deposits.@en;A very dark to dark grey clayey

column13: Neogene and early Pleistocene bedrock formations
column14: and in eastern East Anglia also unconformably overlies the older glacigenic Happisburgh Formation (formerly Corton Formation on some maps) and the fluvial sands and gravels of the Dunwich Group. The tills within the Lowestoft Formation typically contain a significantly higher percentage of chalk than the underlying tills. The gravels in the Dunwich Group contain a significant amount of quartzose lithologies and only very minor quantities of erratics and chalk

column17: 'There is some debate as to the extent of the Lowestoft Formation. It is extensive over East Anglia having its southern limit near Romford
column18: Essex. It is probable that most of the chalky tills in central East Anglia are also part of the Lowestoft Formation. In northern East Anglia the very chalky tills commonly referred to informally as the "marly drift" were generally included within the Lowestoft Formation
column19: but recent work has indicated that these may belong to a younger glaciation. Likewise
column20: chalky tills in the south and east Midlands have commonly been linked with the Lowestoft Formation
column21: but these may also be younger. It is also uncertain how the pre-Devensian tills in Lincolnshire relate to the Lowestoft Formation.@en'
column25: 'The Lowestoft Formation is overlain unconformably by deposits of the Britannia Catchments Group and in northeastern East Anglia by the Sheringham Cliffs Formation. Where the uppermost part of the Lowestoft Formation comprises sand and gravel
column26: it is not always easy to determine its upper boundary if overlain by younger sand and gravel
column27: but in general the younger sand and gravel is better sorted and chalk free.@en'
