column352: fluvial deposits). Remnants may be present inside the Devensian limit beneath the Stockport Formation.@en;The Briton's Lane Formation forms the uppermost stratigraphical units in northern Norfolk. However
column353: sporadic palaeosols can be observed within the upper part of the deposit such as at Briton's Lane.@en'
column358: 'Central Grampian (Albion) Glacigenic Subgroup@en;Shetland (Albion) Glacigenic Subgroup@en;East Grampian (Albion) Glacigenic Subgroup@en;Logie-Buchan (Albion) Glacigenic Subgroup@en;Mearns (Albion) Glacigenic Subgroup@en;Happisburgh Glacigenic Formation@en;Inverness (Albion) Glacigenic Subgroup@en;Irish Sea Coast (Albion) Glacigenic Subgroup@en;Sheringham Cliffs Formation@en;Western Isles (Albion) Glacigenic Subgroup@en;Wolston Formation@en;Banffshire Coast And Caithness (Albion) Glacigenic Subgroup@en;Kenn Formation@en;North Sea Coast (Albion) Glacigenic Subgroup@en;Nurseries Formation@en;Northwest Highlands (Albion) Glacigenic Subgroup@en;Lowestoft Formation@en;Ridgacre Formation@en;Briton\'s Lane Formation@en'
column362: 'Mid Pleistocene.@en;Mid Pleistocene.@en;Mid Pleistocene (MI Stage 12 and/or 10).@en;Early Pleistoocene to Mid Pleistocene.@en;Mid Pleistocene (MI Stage 12).@en;Pleistocene (Anglian).@en;Mid Pleistocene.@en'
column371: '(A) The name follows Bowen et al (1999) and BGS provisional Framework document. (B) The consensus view in academia is that this unit is Stage 12 (as per Bowen 1999)
column372: but there is evidence to suggest it is younger Stage 10
column373: or both 10 and 12. (C) The succession within the Wolston Formation is only touched upon; neither the Wolston Clay Member nor the synonymous Grounds Farm Member are mentioned. (D) The precise limits of the Wolston Formation are contentious. It could be taken to the Devensian limit in Lincolnshire but Lewis (in Bowen
column374: 1999) excluded things such as the Wragby Till (putting it in the Lowestoft Formation)
column375: which could be included in the Wolston Formation. Thus the limit in the east is fairly arbitrary
column376: and the northern limit is particularly vague
column377: and probably best left as such until some primary work has been done on the older drifts of the south Pennines area. (E) As this unit is not actually distinguished on any BGS maps (locally its component members are) the listing of 50K sheets is actually superfluous
column378: but a list is included to show the areas where the Wolston Formation should encompass the glacial deposits.@en;(A) Name follows Bowen et al. (1999) and the provisional BGS Framework
column379: but should it be Nurseries Glacigenic Formation? (B) There is little dispute about its Stage 12 Anglian age. That it lies below ?Hoxnian? organics is an important part of the argument for two pre-Late Devensian glaciations - see also comments on Ridgacre Formation - but this is largely dependent on the exact age of the organics
column380: which is still contentious. (C) By definition this is the older of the two pre-Devensian glacial successions identified in the Birmingham area. It was separated by Kelly in his sections of M-way boreholes
column381: which suggest it is quite extensive beneath the Ridgacre in north Birmingham. Neither he nor Horton give sufficient data to characterise it fully lithologically so it is not possible to state the full range of lithology nor its lateral extent. Survey of the Birmingham district (Powell et al
column382: 2000) threw no further light on the problem
column383: except that most of the tills are described as reddish and Trias-rich
column384: which sounds more like the younger Ridgeacre Formation. (D) Glacigenic deposits are widespread beyond the Devensian limit in the Midlands but they have not been separated into two phases (except perhaps where stratigraphy is clear in the Wolston Formation). If there is a southern or eastern limit to the Ridgacre within the area (see Maddy et al.
column385: 1995) and the Nurseries Formation extends beyond it
column386: it would mean that the latter is widespread at surface and constitutes much of the western older drift to the west of obvious northern and eastern Wolston Formation. Much more work is needed. (E) This unit is not yet distinguished on any maps
column387: so the information related to 50K maps indicates where the Nurseries Formation (and/or Ridgacre) might occur.@en;(A) As in Bowen et al (1999) and new BGS scheme. Should it be Ridgacre Glacigenic Formation? (B) Age left vague. Overlying ?Hoxnian? organics it is part of support for two pre-Late Devensian glaciations. Those envisaging a 2-phase Anglian put the unit in MIS 10
column388: with the Oadby Till. Others put it in 6
column389: based on relationship with Severn terraces
column390: mirroring arguments based on the Avon/Severn/Thames that imply a Stage 10 Oadby Till (+ Ridgacre)! Avon/Severn relationships must be sorted out. Ridgacre at Quinton and Nechells could be Upper Pleistocene 4
column392: as the ?Hoxnian? beds age is uncertain. (C) This is the younger of two pre-Devensian glacial sequences at Quinton and Nechells. Not separated by BGS but Kelly?s (1964) sections suggest Ridgacre must be widespread
column393: at least in north Birmingham. Neither Kelly nor Horton give enough lithological data to characterize the unit fully. Until lateral extent is known
column394: full range of lithologies is unknown; a Catch 22! (D) Widespread glacigenic deposits beyond Devensian limit in the Midlands are not separated into two phases (except in Wolston Formation). As representing the later episode it might be safe to say most pre-Devensian glacial deposits on Birmingham area maps are Ridgacre
column395: and that Nurseries might be limited to buried pockets
column396: as at Quinton and Nechells. Birmingham area survey (Powell et al
column398: shed little light ? most tills reddish and Trias rich
column399: more like Ridgeacre than Nurseries. Ridgacre?s southern limit could be within the area and Nurseries extend beyond
column400: with both at outcrop. Other problems are deciding Ridgacre?s eastern limit
column401: where it becomes part of Wolston Formation
column402: and how far north it goes. Maddy?s model suggests not far but
column404: it could be widespread. This could be settled by more research and study of lithologies beyond the Devensian limit. (E) The unit is not distinguished on BGS maps
column405: so the list of 50K maps shows where the Ridgacre MIGHT occur.@en'

column150: 'Matrix-rich red-brown clayey gravel containing cobbles of schistose semipelite
column153: sandstone and some chalk flints locally.@en;Diamicton
column156: strong brown or yellowish brown. Mostly rock types derived short distance to the northwest. Locally containing flint and quartzite from the Buchan Ridge Gravels.@en;Dominantly brown/dark brown
column160: gravelly slightly clayey silty sand diamicton. Clast lithologies are dominated by quartzite/psammite and red brown Devonian sandstones
column163: grey granite and mafic igneous rocks. Clasts are typically subangular - subrounded (with the pelitic metasedimentary rocks commonly striated). Clast fabrics indicate glacial transport from the northwest. Interpreted as a subglacial till.@en;Sandy gravel and gravelly sand
column164: very pale brown to pale brown pebble to cobble grade
column165: clast-supported with quartzose medium to coarse sand matrix; locally sand with dispersed pebbles. Clast angularity is variable from subangular to rounded. Clast lithologies are dominated by psammitic and quartzite metasedimentary rock
column169: red and grey granites and red sandstone. The sediments display tabular cross beds showing palaeocurrent from the northwest
column170: and crude horizontal bedding. Interpreted as either a proglacial or subglacial glaciofluvial sediment.@en;Diamicton
column173: matrix supported
column176: silty sand. Clast types include pebbles and cobbles of quartzitic and psammitic and pelitic metasedimentary rocks
column181: red sandstone and red-stained quartzite. Clast fabric indicates glacial transport from the northwest. In the northwest and northeast faces of Leys Quarry (disused) thin beds of deformed and attenuated silty fine to medium sand are present. Interpreted as a subglacial till.@en;Gravel with subsidiary beds of sand. Dominantly pale olive brown and pale pinkish brown pebble-cobble-boulder gravels. Typically clast supported with medium to coarse quartzose and felsitic sand matrix. Clasts are typically subrounded and rounded and dominated by felsite with less common metasediments
column182: red granites and mafic igneous lithologies. Sand interbeds are medium to coarse grained and both felsitic and quartzose. Locally the gravels and sands display Fe and Mn stains and cements. The deposit displays large-scale cross-beds and is locally deformed (faulted and folded by ice melt-out). Palaeocurrent analysis indicates transport to the northwest
column183: west and southwest. Interpreted as glaciodeltaic and glaciofluvial outwash.@en;Gravel
column190: silty sand diamicton. Dominantly pale olive-brown and olive-brown (upper interval shows extensive yellowish brown and strong brown mottling). Non-calcareous
column193: slightly clayey silty sand. Clast types include quartzites
column194: psammitic and pelitic metasedimentary rocks
column196: mafic igneous rocks and grey granite. The lower intervals contain lenses and small rafts of kaolinised metasedimentary rocks and grussified mafic igneous rocks. Interpreted as a subglacial till.@en;Gravel
column198: clast or matrix-supported mass movement or waterlain deposit. Clasts angular to subrounded; matrix silty sand.@en;Sand with subsidiary beds of gravel. Dominantly pale olive-brown and pale pinkish brown quartzose and felsitic medium to coarse sand. Typically horizontally stratified with some planar and trough cross beds indicating transport towards the west. The gravel component diminishes upwards and is typically of pebble-cobble grade. Angularity varies significantly from rounded to angular. Clast lithologies are dominated by felsite
column201: hornfels and red and grey granites. Interpretated as a periglacial fluvial deposit (possibly glaciofluvial in part).@en;A clayey gravel and yellowish brown sand
column202: with subrounded to well-rounded pebbles of psammite

column167: lacustrine and organic deposits of the Proto-Soar and Bytham rivers. Deposits of four separate river terrace levels are recognised as members of the Ingham Formation. Commonly a basal sandy gravel is overlain by pebbly sands
column168: with few clay and silt beds. The gravels of all contain a high proportion of rounded pebbles of grey and purple "Bunter" quartzite of Triassic derivation
column170: Jurassic and Cretaceous rocks are local important constituents. Sedimentary structures indicate deposition by braided rivers.@en;Unbedded and thickly bedded cobble gravel with interbedded coarse sands. Gravels are dominantly nodular flint to 0.2m diameter
column171: with subordinate quartz and Greensand chert. The sand is subangular
column173: and occurs as horizontal planar-bedded units
column175: and channel-fill sands and silts. Fluvial and periglacial in origin
column176: deposited by rivers draining to the northwest. Well-defined palaeosol in upper part of gravelly deposits
column177: overlain by silty fine sand of aeolian origin.@en;Encompasses fluvial
column178: lacustrine and organic deposits of the pre-diversionary River Thames
column179: and the pre-glacial soils developed on such deposits. Most of the surviving deposits are fluvial gravels
column180: with sedimentary structures indicating deposition by a braided river. Lacustrine silts and clays and organic peats are uncommon. The gravels are characterised by quartz and quartzite from the Triassic
column181: Carboniferous and Devonian rocks of the West Midlands
column182: Welsh Borderland and possibly southwestern Pennines
column183: and by felsic volcanic rocks from northern Wales. The presence of mega-erratics and glacially-fractured sand grains indicate glacial erosion in the headwater regions of the river. The fluvial gravels occupy terrace levels and formations and members are defined on the basis of altitude and pebble clast content. The members comprise bodies of cross-bedded and massive
column184: moderately sorted sand and gravel. The aggradations are generally entrenched into bedrock with a difference in surface elevation of at least 5m. The upper part of the gravels which dominate the subgroup are commonly affected by pedogenesis. The Valley Farm Soil is a rubified and clay-enriched horizon affecting the top 1.0-1.5m and indicating warm interglacial conditions. The Barham Arctic Structure Soil is a complex pedogenic horizon affecting the topmost 1.0-1.5m of the subgroup and of the Valley Farm Soil (Rose and Allen 1976
column185: Rose et al 1985).@en;The formation encompasses the fluvial
column186: lacustrine and organic deposits of the postulated "Ancaster River"
column187: which is believed to have flowed from the Pennines to the North Sea along a line corresponding approximately to the present north coast of Norfolk. Four members are recognised in north Norfolk coastal sections. The Sheringham Member (lowest member) comprises freshwater organic mud
column188: clay and sand. The Runton Member includes laminated freshwater silty clay. The West Runton Member comprises layers of alluvial clay and organic freshwater mud. The Bacton Member (highest Member) comprises clay and organic mud.@en;Gravel and sandy gravel; sub-angular

column25: '(A) The unit is referred to here as Cropthorne Sand and Gravel Member
column27: and in previous BGS use it was simply Cropthorne Member. (B) Terrace surface typically some 11 to 15m above modern Avon alluvial floodplain in the Rugby area
column28: increasing downstream to c.25m near the confluence with the Severn at Tewkesbury. (C) The upper boundary is given as "ground surface" though head
column29: colluvium or soil deposits may intervene. (D) All Avon (and Severn) terraces need review; classification of some outcrops on existing maps is dubious. Thus some Previous Names are necessarily approximate.However
column31: it appears that the Cropthorne (Avon 4) meets the Kidderminster Station (Severn 4) fairly convincingly. (E) Accounts prior to Bowen (1999) include deposits now separated as the Strensham Member.@en'
column52: 'Predominantly cold phase sands and gravels that underlie the Avon Fourth Terrace of Tomlinson (1925) and of BGS maps. Dominated by clasts of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite lithologies with subordinate flint. Locally includes the organic Ailstone Bed
column54: at its base. Probably equates with the Kidderminster Station Member of the Severn Valley Formation. (See also Compiler's notes under Supplementary Information.)@en'
column61: 'Mid Pleistocene to Holocene (MI Stages ?11 or 9 to 1).@en'
column65: commonly channelled base on pre-Quaternary (mostly Triassic and Jurassic with some Carboniferous) bedrock
column67: sands and gravels) of the Wolston Formation
column68: or pre-glacial fluvial sands and gravels of the Baginton Formation.@en'
column80: 'Fluvial terrace and alluvial deposits of the Warwickshire River Avon and all its tributaries; mainly sand
column82: and mud; divided into six [or seven] "terrace" members (Frog Hall
column89: 1999) and with local named organic deposits. Includes contemporaneous head
column90: colluvium and soil deposits. Gravels are principally composed of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite
column93: Wolston Formation and the local bedrock of the catchment.@en'
column95: '(A) Renamed the Warwickshire Avon Valley Formation to avoid confusion with the Bristol Avon Valley Formation. Other possibilities might have been Warwick or Stratford or even Midland Avon
column96: the last having been used in the titles of some papers. (B) It is impractical to give a fully comprehensive definition of the base in lithological terms.@en'
column124: 'The Severn and Avon Catchments Subgroup encompasses all the fluvial
column125: lacustrine and organic deposits of the rivers that occupy the catchment areas of the River Severn
column128: those rivers which flow from Wales into the Bristol Channel as far as Port Talbot
column129: and all their tributaries. Floodplain alluvium comprises soft silts and clays
column130: commonly with beds of peat and a basal bed of sand and gravel. River terrace deposits are largely sand and gravel. The gravels include a wide range of Palaeozoic and Mesozoic rocks
column131: and much glacial material. Peat is a minor component
column132: and minor marine deposits are included where they are intercalated in dominantly fluvial formations.@en'
column135: 'Formations of the Severn and Avon Catchments Subgroup rest unconformably on glacial and periglacial deposits and on a wide range of Palaeozoic and Mesozoic bedrock.@en'
column136: 'The entire area covered by the catchments of the River Severn
column139: those rivers which flow from Wales into the Bristol Channel as far west as Port Talbot
column160: largely within a minor un-named tributary of the River Leam ("Alluvial fan gravels" of BGS Sheet 184).@en;Only currently recognised at Upper Strensham SO905 395 (BGS Sheets 199
column176: 216).@en;Avon Valley from Wasperton (just downstream of Warwick) to Tewkesbury.@en;Avon Valley and tributaries (BGS Sheets 183
column186: clay or peat. [Generic description].@en;Sand and gravel
column187: with possible lenses of silt clay or peat. [Generic description].@en;Predominantly cold phase sands and gravels that infill a channel incised
column188: to a level several metres below the Dunsmore Gravel "plateau"
column189: into the Wolston Formation and underlying Triassic bedrock and grade southwards into the valley of the River Leam (a principal Avon tributary). Lithologically similar to the Dunsmore Gravel Member (Wolston Formation)
column190: being dominated by clasts of Triassic ("Bunter") lithologies and flint
column192: and also containing clasts of ironpan (ferricrete) derived from Dunsmore Gravel. At the type locality it includes organic peaty deposits ("Frog Member") assigned to MIS 9 at base. Probably contemporaneous with the Pershore Member (Avon Valley Formation).@en;Predominantly cold phase sands and gravels that underlie a terrace supposedly intermediate in height between  the Cropthorne (4) and Pershore members (5) of the Avon Fourth Terrace of Tomlinson (1925) and of BGS maps. Dominated by clasts of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite lithologies with subordinate flint. Terrace surface at type locality approximately 40-42m OD
column194: some 30m above the modern Avon. Overlies the organic Strensham Court Bed (Bowen
column196: = the Strensham Bed of de Rouffignac (1995)
column197: assigned to Stage 7. (See Supplementary Information Description).@en;Predominantly cold phase sands and gravels that underlie the Avon Fourth Terrace of Tomlinson (1925) and of BGS maps. Dominated by clasts of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite lithologies with subordinate flint. Locally includes the organic Ailstone Bed
column199: at its base. Probably equates with the Kidderminster Station Member of the Severn Valley Formation. (See also Compiler's notes under Supplementary Information.)@en;Predominantly cold phase sands and gravels that underlie the Avon Fifth Terrace of Tomlinson (1925) and of BGS maps (sheets 199
column200: 200 and 215). Dominated by clasts of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite lithologies with subordinate flint.@en;Predominantly cold phase sands and gravels that underlie the Avon  Second Terrace of Tomlinson (1925) and of BGS Maps. Dominated by clasts of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite lithologies with subordinate flint. Locally includes the organic Fladbury Bed
column201: which is "Mid Devensian" although the precise age is controversial. Probably correlates with Holt Heath Member of the Severn Valley Formation.@en;Sand and gravel: New Inn Terrace Deposits: gravel includes 'Bunter' type clasts
column202: and mammalian bones; Ailstone Terrace Deposits: glacial and interglacial features and fossiliferous; third and fourth terraces of the River Avon; part of the Avon Valley Formation. [Generic description: academic papers and BGS Memoirs].@en;Predominantly cold phase sands and gravels that underlie the Avon Third Terrace of Tomlinson (1925) and of BGS maps. Dominated by clasts of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite lihtologies with subordinate flint. Locally includes organic Eckington Bed (or New Inn Fossil Bed) at base
column203: which is assigned to MIS 5e. Correlation with members of Severn Valley Formation problematical. See Compiler's Notes under Supplementary Information.@en;Predominantly cold phase sands and gravels that underlie the Avon First Terrace of Tomlinson (1925) and of BGS Maps. Dominated by clasts of "Bunter" quartz/quartzite lithologies with subordinate flint
column204: generally somewhat finer in grade than older members. (See also Compiler's notes under Supplementary Information).@en'

column11: 'The basal boundary of the Starston Till Member is abrupt and commonly erosional. The Member overlyies Bytham River (Bytham Catchment Subgroup) deposits at the stratotype locality
column12: where a lithological change from sand and gravel to till can be observed.@en'
column13: 'Buried beneath Lowestoft Formation till at depth within the Diss and Harleston districts
column18: 'The upper boundary of the Starston Till Member with overlying glaciofluvial outwash (un-named) is erosional. Hollows on the upper surface of the till are commonly infilled by a coarse gravel lag.@en'
column38: 'Brown clayey-sand matrix-supported diamicton with flint and sporadic chalk pebbles. Laminations are common.@en'
column48: 'The lower boundary of the Happisburgh Formation is commonly erosional in northeast Norfolk and the Waveney Valley and truncates shallow marine deposits of the Wroxham Crag Formation. More rarely
column49: such as at sites like Leet Hill in southern Norfolk
column50: coarse-grained outwash deposits (the Leet Hill Sand and Gravel Member) exhibit a gradational lower contact with river terrace deposits of the Bytham Catchment Subgroup.@en'
column53: 'The upper boundary of the Happisburgh Formation is erosional and angular
column54: and truncated by the more chalky tills of the Lowestoft Formation.@en'
column65: sands and laminated silts and clays. The diamictons (Happisburgh Till
column66: Corton Till and California Till members) are typically sandy matrix-supported diamictons that contain a high abundance of flint and quartzose lithologies relative to chalk
column67: distinguishing them from the more chalky tills of the overlying Lowestoft Formation.@en'
column75: 'The southern limit of the Happisburgh Glacigenic Formation occurs within the Lowestoft district. From there it can be traced northwards across the Great Yarmouth
column77: and westwards onto the Norwich and Diss sheets. In coastal sections
column78: deposits of the formation can be observed discontinuously between Pakefield (near Lowestoft) to Overstrand in northeast Norfolk.@en'

column134: 'Mapped out in the Banham - Kenninghall - Quidenham area; for exact distribution see Diss Memoir
column135: figure 9.@en;The California Till Member has been logged in cliff sections between California Gap and Scratby to the north of Great Yarmouth
column136: and occurs as separate mappable leaves of till inland in the Great Yarmouth and North Walsham districts.@en;The deposit has been mapped extensively throughout the Yarmouth and Lowestoft districts.@en;Cliffs sections between Happisburgh Coastguard Station and Happisburgh lighthouse
column137: northeast Norfolk.@en;The Happisburgh Till Member can be observed in coastal sections between Happisburgh and Overstrand in northeast Norfolk.@en;Buried beneath Lowestoft Formation till at depth within the Diss and Harleston districts
column143: silts and clays characterized by abundant quartz-quartzite pebbles.@en;The California Till Member consists of a stratified matrix-supported diamicton that comprises beds of massive brown sandy diamicton
column144: separated by beds of massive and horizontal-bedded chalky sand with sporadic augen-shaped lenses of fine silty sand. It is similar in lithology to the Corton Till Member.@en;Stratified and channelled proximal glaciofluvial outwash deposits. Lithologically
column145: the gravels are rich in flint and quartzose clasts
column146: and contain erratics of northern provenance including Old Red Sandstone
column148: dolerite and Carboniferous limestone. Palaeocurrent measurements reveal flow originally towards the northeast when constrained by the Bytham River valley
column149: and then southwards as the river valley was infilled by outwash sediment.@en;The Happisburgh Sand Member consists of yellowish brown and yellow-orange stratrified sands. The sands exhibit a range of bedding structures including planar and trough cross-bedding
column152: channel structures and sporadic horizons of convolute bedding.@en;The Happisburgh Till Member is a yellowish grey to grey matrix-supported diamicton that has a sandy clay matrix texture. The clast content of the diamicton is <1\% and composed predominantly of flint
column153: vein quartz and quartzite with a subsidiary assemblage of far-travelled British erratic lithologies including Carboniferous limestone
column159: Dalradian metasediments. The diamicton has been interpreted as a subglacial deformation till.@en;Brown clayey-sand matrix-supported diamicton with flint and sporadic chalk pebbles. Laminations are common.@en'
column162: 'Resting unconformably on Upper Chalk@en;The California Till Member overlies the Corton Sand Member within the Scratby and California area. The contact between the two units is gradational.@en;The lower boundary of the Leet Hill Sand and Gravel Member truncates either the diamicton facies of the Corton Till Member or older stratified sands of the Wroxham Crag Formation sediments. Locally
column164: the outwash and underlying fluvial sediments (Bytham Catchments Subgroup) form a gradational fluvial to glacial outwash continuum.@en;The transition from the laminated silts and clays of the Ostend Clay Member (also part of the Happisburgh Formation) to the sandy facies of the Happisburgh Sand Member is erosional and marked by a thin gravel lag.@en;The basal contact between the Happisburgh Till Member and the underlying Wroxham Crag Formation is represented by an upward transition from tidally laminated sand and silt to till.@en;The basal boundary of the Starston Till Member is abrupt and commonly erosional. The Member overlyies Bytham River (Bytham Catchment Subgroup) deposits at the stratotype locality
column165: where a lithological change from sand and gravel to till can be observed.@en'
column167: 'Banham Member@en;California Till Member@en;Corton Till Member@en;Leet Hill Sand And Gravel Member@en;Happisburgh Sand Member@en;Happisburgh Till Member@en;Starston Till Member@en'
column171: 'Max. 9m@en;Maximum observed thickness of 13m at California Gap.@en;The deposit thickens westwards from Corton (0.8m) to around 9m in the vicinity of Leet Hill.@en;Varies between 6 and 8m@en;Typically between 2 to 7m@en;To 7m@en'
column172: 'Overlain abruptly by deposits of glacigenic Lowestoft Formation.@en;The upper boundary of the California Till Member is typically scoured and erosional
column173: and is overlain by chalky outwash and till deposits of the Lowestoft Formation.@en;The upper boundary of the Leet Hill Sand and Gravel Member with the overlying Corton Sand Member is abrupt but conformable.@en;The transition from the sandy Happisburgh Sand Member to the diamicton facies of the Corton Till Member is erosional.@en;The upper boundary of the Happisburgh Till Member is variable but generally consists of a series of ridges and troughs that have been interpreted as a range of subglacial and ice-marginal landforms. The till is overlain by a series of laminated clays (Ostend Clay Member) and sands (Happisburgh Sand Member).@en;The upper boundary of the Starston Till Member with overlying glaciofluvial outwash (un-named) is erosional. Hollows on the upper surface of the till are commonly infilled by a coarse gravel lag.@en'

column79: '(A) The name may need changing if it is decided that the Upper Severn should be excluded. Obviously Lower Severn would seem appropriate. The Upper Severn is entirely within the Devensian limit - in pre-Devensian times it was probably a tributary of the Dee.This is a common problem with rivers that have had major diversions during the Pleistocene e.g. Thames and Trent. (B) The list of members relates to the ?lower Severn? below Bridgnorth but even there might not be fully comprehensive if ?awkward? rivers like the Teme (see below) are included. (C) It is impractical to give a fully comprehensive definition of the base in lithological terms. (D) The Upper Boundary might need modification if head etc is not included in this type of Formation. (E) Thickness estimates are subject to possible modification. (F) Listed 50K sheets are those that include a portion of the entire Severn catchment. More work might be needed to decide if some rivers like the Teme (the valley of which includes pre-Devensian terraces related to the River Wye!)
column80: or indeed the Upper (later Devensian) Severn (see above) should be included.@en'
column107: 'The Severn and Avon Catchments Subgroup encompasses all the fluvial
column108: lacustrine and organic deposits of the rivers that occupy the catchment areas of the River Severn
column111: those rivers which flow from Wales into the Bristol Channel as far as Port Talbot
column112: and all their tributaries. Floodplain alluvium comprises soft silts and clays
column113: commonly with beds of peat and a basal bed of sand and gravel. River terrace deposits are largely sand and gravel. The gravels include a wide range of Palaeozoic and Mesozoic rocks
column114: and much glacial material. Peat is a minor component
column115: and minor marine deposits are included where they are intercalated in dominantly fluvial formations.@en'
column118: 'Formations of the Severn and Avon Catchments Subgroup rest unconformably on glacial and periglacial deposits and on a wide range of Palaeozoic and Mesozoic bedrock.@en'

column79: '(A) The name may need changing if it is decided that the Upper Severn should be excluded. Obviously Lower Severn would seem appropriate. The Upper Severn is entirely within the Devensian limit - in pre-Devensian times it was probably a tributary of the Dee.This is a common problem with rivers that have had major diversions during the Pleistocene e.g. Thames and Trent. (B) The list of members relates to the ?lower Severn? below Bridgnorth but even there might not be fully comprehensive if ?awkward? rivers like the Teme (see below) are included. (C) It is impractical to give a fully comprehensive definition of the base in lithological terms. (D) The Upper Boundary might need modification if head etc is not included in this type of Formation. (E) Thickness estimates are subject to possible modification. (F) Listed 50K sheets are those that include a portion of the entire Severn catchment. More work might be needed to decide if some rivers like the Teme (the valley of which includes pre-Devensian terraces related to the River Wye!)
column80: or indeed the Upper (later Devensian) Severn (see above) should be included.@en'

column78: '(A) The name follows Bowen et al (1999) and BGS provisional Framework document. (B) The consensus view in academia is that this unit is Stage 12 (as per Bowen 1999)
column79: but there is evidence to suggest it is younger Stage 10
column80: or both 10 and 12. (C) The succession within the Wolston Formation is only touched upon; neither the Wolston Clay Member nor the synonymous Grounds Farm Member are mentioned. (D) The precise limits of the Wolston Formation are contentious. It could be taken to the Devensian limit in Lincolnshire but Lewis (in Bowen
column81: 1999) excluded things such as the Wragby Till (putting it in the Lowestoft Formation)
column82: which could be included in the Wolston Formation. Thus the limit in the east is fairly arbitrary
column83: and the northern limit is particularly vague
column84: and probably best left as such until some primary work has been done on the older drifts of the south Pennines area. (E) As this unit is not actually distinguished on any BGS maps (locally its component members are) the listing of 50K sheets is actually superfluous
column85: but a list is included to show the areas where the Wolston Formation should encompass the glacial deposits.@en'

column98: '(A) The name may need changing if it is decided that the Upper Severn should be excluded. Obviously Lower Severn would seem appropriate. The Upper Severn is entirely within the Devensian limit - in pre-Devensian times it was probably a tributary of the Dee.This is a common problem with rivers that have had major diversions during the Pleistocene e.g. Thames and Trent. (B) The list of members relates to the ?lower Severn? below Bridgnorth but even there might not be fully comprehensive if ?awkward? rivers like the Teme (see below) are included. (C) It is impractical to give a fully comprehensive definition of the base in lithological terms. (D) The Upper Boundary might need modification if head etc is not included in this type of Formation. (E) Thickness estimates are subject to possible modification. (F) Listed 50K sheets are those that include a portion of the entire Severn catchment. More work might be needed to decide if some rivers like the Teme (the valley of which includes pre-Devensian terraces related to the River Wye!)
column99: or indeed the Upper (later Devensian) Severn (see above) should be included.@en'

column247: '(A) The unit is referred to here as the Frog Hall Member as this is the name used in Bowen 1999. For consistency with other members in this part of the framework it should perhaps be Frog Hall Sand and Gravel Member. (B) The temperate ?Frog Member? (= Frog Hall Bed[s] of manuscripts) is included here in the Frog Hall [Sand and Gravel] Member
column248: though Maddy had this as a member in its own right in Bowen (1999). (C) The upper boundary is given as ?ground surface? though head
column249: colluvium or soil deposits may intervene.@en;(a) This unit may be superfluous in the Avon scheme. (b) The "terrace" top and deposit base at the type locality lie within the 4th/Cropthorne envelope
column250: suggesting the deposits should be classified as Cropthorne Member. Supposed MIS 7 organic deposits beneath it strengthen the case. (c) However
column251: it has been mapped as Terrace 5/Pershore Member. It does indeed lie 6m or so above a nearby terrace outcrop mapped as Terrace 4/Cropthorne. If it were Pershore Member MIS 9 organics might be expected beneath it. "Dating" to MIS7
column252: based solely on "aminostratigraphy"
column253: could be wrong - apparently C fluminalis (to strengthen the Stage 7 case) has not been found. (d) Thus an extra Member is not needed: the unit should be reclassified as Cropthorne (ie BGS maps are wrong) or as Pershore Member. The former is most likely: probably it is a dissected remnant of a valley-side head fan
column256: and somewhat higher than the true Cropthorne terrace flat. Such fans extending uphill from the Cropthorne terrace are commonplace in the upper Avon. (d) Terrace surface at type locality c.40-42m OD
column257: ie
column258: c.30m above the modern Avon. (e) Upper boundary described as ?ground surface? but head might intervene.[Precis of notes from MGS]@en;(A) The unit is referred to here as Cropthorne Sand and Gravel Member
column259: though in Bowen 1999
column260: and in previous BGS use it was simply Cropthorne Member. (B) Terrace surface typically some 11 to 15m above modern Avon alluvial floodplain in the Rugby area
column261: increasing downstream to c.25m near the confluence with the Severn at Tewkesbury. (C) The upper boundary is given as "ground surface" though head
column262: colluvium or soil deposits may intervene. (D) All Avon (and Severn) terraces need review; classification of some outcrops on existing maps is dubious. Thus some Previous Names are necessarily approximate.However
column263: despite problems with lower terraces
column264: it appears that the Cropthorne (Avon 4) meets the Kidderminster Station (Severn 4) fairly convincingly. (E) Accounts prior to Bowen (1999) include deposits now separated as the Strensham Member.@en;(A) Here named the Pershore Sand and Gravel Member though in Bowen (1999) and also in the previous BGS list of computer codes it is simply Pershore Member. (B) Terrace surface some 40m above modern Avon alluvial floodplain at type locality
column265: where it includes the organic Allesborough Bed (the Pershore Fossil bed of Maddy et al.
column266: 1991) at base
column267: which is assigned to MIS 9. Probably equates with Frog Hall Member of the upstream Avon/Leam
column268: and with Bushley Green Member of the Severn Valley Formation. (C) Upper Boundary is given as ?ground surface? though there may be head
column269: colluvium or soil deposits intervening. (D) The Avon
column270: and also Severn
column271: terraces need reviewing in their entirety and the classification of some outcrops on existing maps is suspect
column272: so the list of Previous Names is necessarily an approximation. It is likely that some deposits classified as Pershore (Terrace 5) on existing maps are too low and should actually be classified as Cropthorne (4). That aside
column273: despite some problems of correlation with other terraces
column274: on the basis of elevation
column275: it seems that the correspondence of the Pershore and Bushley Green members between the Avon and Severn
column276: is fairly good.@en;(A) Here named the Wasperton Sand and Gravel though it is simply Wasperton Member in Bowen 1999
column277: and in the previous BGS list of computer codes. (B) Dating of this terrace is contentious; as yet the crucial Fladbury Bed beneath it has no age-diagnostic fauna and its C14 date of c.38K (within MIS 3) may be a minimum. (C) Terrace surface typically some 5m above modern Avon alluvial floodplain in the Rugby area
column278: increasing downstream to c.9m near the confluence with the Severn at Tewkesbury. (D) All things being equal
column279: one this unit might be expected to correspond with the Holt Heath (3) of the Severn (Late Devensian outwash terrace) but the latter seems a few metres lower at the Avon confluence (Tewkesbury) so this isn?t as might be hoped. On the other hand
column280: the Wasperton is too high to meet the Worcester (Terrace 2) of the Severn too! Actually as both the Holt Heath and Wasperton are composite
column282: none of this is greatly surprising Nevertheless there might be a problem both with the classification of the Severn terraces
column283: and those of the Avon. (E) The upper boundary is given as ?ground surface? though head
column284: colluvium or soil deposits might intervene. (F) Avon and Severn terraces need reviewing in their entirety and classification of some outcrops on existing maps is highly suspect. Thus the Previous Names are necessarily an approximation. (G) Only 50K maps on the main course of the Avon are listed. Terrace 2 appears on several other maps in the catchment
column285: up tributary steams and so on
column286: (see Warwickshire Avon Valley Formation for complete list) but whether this is really the Wasperton Member is unclear.@en;(A) The unit is referred to here as the New Inn Sand and Gravel Member though in Bowen (1999)
column287: and in previous BGS use it was simply New Inn Member. (B) The terrace surface is some 15m above the modern Avon alluvial floodplain (e.g at type locality) apparently decreasing to perhaps 10m downstream. (C) The terrace is not well defined morphologically and it seems too high and close to Terrace 4 (Cropthorne). Moreover
column288: on the basis of elevation
column289: it looks as if some supposed Terrace 3 downstream might actually be Terrace 2 (or less probably
column290: vice versa). It might actually include head or tributary fluvial gravels
column291: perhaps equivalent to older parts of the Wasperton (2) Member which is quite probably composite. Correlation with the Severn is a problem: Terrace 3 (Holt Heath) of the Severn also apparently has 5e organic material beneath
column292: but is outwash from the main Devensian Icesheet
column293: which is supposedly stage 2. In any case
column294: as mapped
column295: the Holt Heath looks too low to meet with the Avon?s New Inn
column296: but could just about relate to the Avon?s Wasperton Member. (D) The upper boundary is given as ?ground surface? though head
column297: colluvium or soil deposits may intervene. (E) As stated above
column298: the Avon and Severn terraces need reviewing in their entirety and classification of some outcrops on existing maps is highly suspect. Hence information relating to  Previous Names is necessarily an approximation.@en;(A) the unit is referred to here as Bretford Sand and Gravel Member
column299: though in Bowen 1999
column300: and in previous BGS use it was simply Bretford Member. (B) Terrace surface is typically some 2m above the modern Avon alluvial floodplain; locally with a lower facet c.1m above the floodplain
column301: with deposits extending beneath the latter. Best developed in the upper Avon. Correlation with members of the Severn Valley Formation is problematical. (C) The upper boundary is given as "ground surface" though head
column302: colluvium or soil deposits may intervene. (D) All Avon (and Severn) terraces need review; classification of some outcrops on existing maps is dubious. Thus some Previous Names are necessarily approximate. In particular the depiction of this Terrace 1 on maps
column303: particularly in the lower Avon
column304: is suspect. It is divided into 1a and 1b "facets"
column305: which might be expected to converge with the Power House (Terrace 1) and Worcester (2) of the Severn
column307: at least
column308: is [supposedly] below the floodplain at the confluence
column310: as far down as the confluence
column311: lie 1 to 2m above. Actually depiction of the Severn Terraces might be wrong; some supposed Terrace 2 "islands" in the floodplain are almost certainly Terrace 1. Knock-on implications are that some of Terrace 3 should be 2
column312: and so on.@en'

column11: 'Taken at the base of the lowest main/significant sandstone in the beds transitional with the underlying St Bees Shale Formation. The base is sharply marked on the gamma-ray log; an abrupt change from a highly serrated signature in the lowermost St Bees Sandstone to a much more subdued signature with higher values in the St Bees Shales.@en'
column14: Vale of Eden. Also includes the 'Lower' St Bees Sandstone of the East Irish Sea Basin.@en'
column18: 'Taken at the sharp upward change from generally fine-grained
column20: with features typical of fluvial deposition
column22: more friable sandstones with common well rounded aeolian grains (Calder Sandstone Formation). Marked also by an abrupt decrease in gamma ray values and increase in sonic interval transit time.@en'

column142: 'The Holkham Till Member is unconformably on older deposits. Locally it overlies gravel of an Ipswichian raised beach in the Hunstanton and Morston areas. Elsewhere it overlies a variety of Lower to Upper Cretaceous formations. There is an abrupt and very obvious lithological change across the boundary from the underlying arenaceous material or chalk
column143: to the clay-silt dominated lithology of the till.@en;The Ringstead Sand and Gravel Member rests unconformably on the Holkham Till Member and a variety of Cretaceous formations. In places it can be difficult or impossible to distinguish the Ringstead Sand and Gravel from the sand and gravel of the older Sheringham Cliffs Formation in adjacent outcrops.@en'

column12: 'The Briton's Lane Sand and Gravel Member is the most extensive part of the Brition's Lane Formation and forms the elevated sections of the Cromer Ridge between the Glavern Valley
column14: north Norfolk. The member also forms some of the large sand and gravel outliers between West Runton and Weybourne and has been traced southwards inland for approximately 10km.@en'
column18: 'The Brition's Lane Sand and Gravel Member is commonly exposed at the surface although in places it has a thick palaeosol developed within the upper 2-3m.@en'
column38: 'The Briton's Land Sand and Gravel Member consists of horizontal
column39: massive and low angle planar cross-bedded gravels and cobble gravels with thin seams of horizontal and rippled sand. The lithology has a distinctive high flint content (c.85-89\%) of which the majority is of non-chatter marked variety (c.78-85\%). The gravels also contain a wide range of far-travelled crystalline erratics including rocks of British and Scandinavian provenance.@en'
column49: 'The lower boundary of the formation is erosional
column50: and sands and gravels truncate earlier deposits of the Sheringham Cliffs Formation.@en'
column53: 'The Briton's Lane Formation forms the uppermost stratigraphical units in northern Norfolk. However
column54: sporadic palaeosols can be observed within the upper part of the deposit such as at Briton's Lane.@en'
column63: 'The Briton's Lane Formation consists of several coarse-grained sand and gravel outwash lithofacies that truncate and drape pre-existing sediments in the Cromer and Mundesley districts. No in-situ till deposits have been identified to date
column64: but thrust slabs of till have been recognised at several localities.@en'
column72: 'The Briton's Lane Formation crops-out across much of northern Norfolk

column140: with subordinate quartz and quartzite. The gravels tend to be strongly imbricated in coastal sections. Inland there are few exposures and they comprise pebbly

column143: with a small (c.6\%) subsidiary quartzose content.@en;The Tottenhill Sand and Gravel Member is a complex sequence of sands and gravels

column147: mostly angular gravels with cross-bedding dipping steeply (20 to 25 degrees) to the southeast

column153: slightly uneven surface along which the upper gravels truncate cryturbation and bedding structures in the lower gravel. The lower unit has no known outcrop.@en;The Briton's Land Sand and Gravel Member consists of horizontal
column154: massive and low angle planar cross-bedded gravels and cobble gravels with thin seams of horizontal and rippled sand. The lithology has a distinctive high flint content (c.85-89\%) of which the majority is of non-chatter marked variety (c.78-85\%). The gravels also contain a wide range of far-travelled crystalline erratics including rocks of British and Scandinavian provenance.@en'

column162: and on the Weybourne Town Till Member within large

column254: '(A) The unit is referred to here as the Frog Hall Member as this is the name used in Bowen 1999. For consistency with other members in this part of the framework it should perhaps be Frog Hall Sand and Gravel Member. (B) The temperate ?Frog Member? (= Frog Hall Bed[s] of manuscripts) is included here in the Frog Hall [Sand and Gravel] Member
column255: though Maddy had this as a member in its own right in Bowen (1999). (C) The upper boundary is given as ?ground surface? though head
column256: colluvium or soil deposits may intervene.@en;(a) This unit may be superfluous in the Avon scheme. (b) The "terrace" top and deposit base at the type locality lie within the 4th/Cropthorne envelope
column257: suggesting the deposits should be classified as Cropthorne Member. Supposed MIS 7 organic deposits beneath it strengthen the case. (c) However
column258: it has been mapped as Terrace 5/Pershore Member. It does indeed lie 6m or so above a nearby terrace outcrop mapped as Terrace 4/Cropthorne. If it were Pershore Member MIS 9 organics might be expected beneath it. "Dating" to MIS7
column259: based solely on "aminostratigraphy"
column260: could be wrong - apparently C fluminalis (to strengthen the Stage 7 case) has not been found. (d) Thus an extra Member is not needed: the unit should be reclassified as Cropthorne (ie BGS maps are wrong) or as Pershore Member. The former is most likely: probably it is a dissected remnant of a valley-side head fan
column261: derived from Pershore gravels
column262: but contemporaneous with the Cropthorne
column263: and somewhat higher than the true Cropthorne terrace flat. Such fans extending uphill from the Cropthorne terrace are commonplace in the upper Avon. (d) Terrace surface at type locality c.40-42m OD
column264: ie
column265: c.30m above the modern Avon. (e) Upper boundary described as ?ground surface? but head might intervene.[Precis of notes from MGS]@en;(A) The unit is referred to here as Cropthorne Sand and Gravel Member
column266: though in Bowen 1999
column267: and in previous BGS use it was simply Cropthorne Member. (B) Terrace surface typically some 11 to 15m above modern Avon alluvial floodplain in the Rugby area
column268: increasing downstream to c.25m near the confluence with the Severn at Tewkesbury. (C) The upper boundary is given as "ground surface" though head
column269: colluvium or soil deposits may intervene. (D) All Avon (and Severn) terraces need review; classification of some outcrops on existing maps is dubious. Thus some Previous Names are necessarily approximate.However
column270: despite problems with lower terraces
column271: it appears that the Cropthorne (Avon 4) meets the Kidderminster Station (Severn 4) fairly convincingly. (E) Accounts prior to Bowen (1999) include deposits now separated as the Strensham Member.@en;(A) Here named the Pershore Sand and Gravel Member though in Bowen (1999) and also in the previous BGS list of computer codes it is simply Pershore Member. (B) Terrace surface some 40m above modern Avon alluvial floodplain at type locality
column272: where it includes the organic Allesborough Bed (the Pershore Fossil bed of Maddy et al.
column273: 1991) at base
column274: which is assigned to MIS 9. Probably equates with Frog Hall Member of the upstream Avon/Leam
column275: and with Bushley Green Member of the Severn Valley Formation. (C) Upper Boundary is given as ?ground surface? though there may be head
column276: colluvium or soil deposits intervening. (D) The Avon
column278: terraces need reviewing in their entirety and the classification of some outcrops on existing maps is suspect
column279: so the list of Previous Names is necessarily an approximation. It is likely that some deposits classified as Pershore (Terrace 5) on existing maps are too low and should actually be classified as Cropthorne (4). That aside
column280: despite some problems of correlation with other terraces
column282: it seems that the correspondence of the Pershore and Bushley Green members between the Avon and Severn
column283: is fairly good.@en;(A) Here named the Wasperton Sand and Gravel though it is simply Wasperton Member in Bowen 1999
column284: and in the previous BGS list of computer codes. (B) Dating of this terrace is contentious; as yet the crucial Fladbury Bed beneath it has no age-diagnostic fauna and its C14 date of c.38K (within MIS 3) may be a minimum. (C) Terrace surface typically some 5m above modern Avon alluvial floodplain in the Rugby area
column285: increasing downstream to c.9m near the confluence with the Severn at Tewkesbury. (D) All things being equal
column286: one this unit might be expected to correspond with the Holt Heath (3) of the Severn (Late Devensian outwash terrace) but the latter seems a few metres lower at the Avon confluence (Tewkesbury) so this isn?t as might be hoped. On the other hand
column287: the Wasperton is too high to meet the Worcester (Terrace 2) of the Severn too! Actually as both the Holt Heath and Wasperton are composite
column288: age-wise
column289: none of this is greatly surprising Nevertheless there might be a problem both with the classification of the Severn terraces
column290: and those of the Avon. (E) The upper boundary is given as ?ground surface? though head
column291: colluvium or soil deposits might intervene. (F) Avon and Severn terraces need reviewing in their entirety and classification of some outcrops on existing maps is highly suspect. Thus the Previous Names are necessarily an approximation. (G) Only 50K maps on the main course of the Avon are listed. Terrace 2 appears on several other maps in the catchment
column292: up tributary steams and so on
column293: (see Warwickshire Avon Valley Formation for complete list) but whether this is really the Wasperton Member is unclear.@en;(A) The unit is referred to here as the New Inn Sand and Gravel Member though in Bowen (1999)
column294: and in previous BGS use it was simply New Inn Member. (B) The terrace surface is some 15m above the modern Avon alluvial floodplain (e.g at type locality) apparently decreasing to perhaps 10m downstream. (C) The terrace is not well defined morphologically and it seems too high and close to Terrace 4 (Cropthorne). Moreover
column295: on the basis of elevation
column296: it looks as if some supposed Terrace 3 downstream might actually be Terrace 2 (or less probably
column297: vice versa). It might actually include head or tributary fluvial gravels
column298: perhaps equivalent to older parts of the Wasperton (2) Member which is quite probably composite. Correlation with the Severn is a problem: Terrace 3 (Holt Heath) of the Severn also apparently has 5e organic material beneath
column299: but is outwash from the main Devensian Icesheet
column300: which is supposedly stage 2. In any case
column301: as mapped
column302: the Holt Heath looks too low to meet with the Avon?s New Inn
column303: but could just about relate to the Avon?s Wasperton Member. (D) The upper boundary is given as ?ground surface? though head
column304: colluvium or soil deposits may intervene. (E) As stated above
column305: the Avon and Severn terraces need reviewing in their entirety and classification of some outcrops on existing maps is highly suspect. Hence information relating to  Previous Names is necessarily an approximation.@en;(A) the unit is referred to here as Bretford Sand and Gravel Member
column307: and in previous BGS use it was simply Bretford Member. (B) Terrace surface is typically some 2m above the modern Avon alluvial floodplain; locally with a lower facet c.1m above the floodplain
column308: with deposits extending beneath the latter. Best developed in the upper Avon. Correlation with members of the Severn Valley Formation is problematical. (C) The upper boundary is given as "ground surface" though head
column309: colluvium or soil deposits may intervene. (D) All Avon (and Severn) terraces need review; classification of some outcrops on existing maps is dubious. Thus some Previous Names are necessarily approximate. In particular the depiction of this Terrace 1 on maps
column311: is suspect. It is divided into 1a and 1b "facets"
column312: which might be expected to converge with the Power House (Terrace 1) and Worcester (2) of the Severn

Commonly including a lower unit that is dark reddish brown.@en;Gravel with subsidiary beds of diamicton and sand. Typically brown/dark brown and olive grey. Dominantly clast supported with a medium to coarse quartzose sand matrix. Clasts are subrounded and rounded and composed mainly of quartzite (probably reworked from Devonian conglomerates) with sparse metasedimentary rock
column155: granites and grey/black ?Mesozoic mudstones. Red sandstone clasts are present in the lowest part of the formation where it directly overlies Devonian red sandstone bedrock. The gravels are crudely horizontally bedded and interbeds of sand show both horizontal stratification and local planar cross bedding. Both gravels and sands display locally strong staining and cementation by Fe and Mn. Palaeocurrent measurements from cross beds and imbricate clasts is towards the south. Common medium beds of yellowish brown gravelly silty sandy diamicton are present and are interpreted as debris flow deposits. The upper 1 to 2m of the deposit display crude involutions and erected clast fabric indicating disruption by periglacial soil processes. Interpreted as glaciofluvial outwash and debris flow deposits.@en;A very dark to dark grey clayey

column78: '(A) The name may need changing if it is decided that the Upper Severn should be excluded. Obviously Lower Severn would seem appropriate. The Upper Severn is entirely within the Devensian limit - in pre-Devensian times it was probably a tributary of the Dee.This is a common problem with rivers that have had major diversions during the Pleistocene e.g. Thames and Trent. (B) The list of members relates to the ?lower Severn? below Bridgnorth but even there might not be fully comprehensive if ?awkward? rivers like the Teme (see below) are included. (C) It is impractical to give a fully comprehensive definition of the base in lithological terms. (D) The Upper Boundary might need modification if head etc is not included in this type of Formation. (E) Thickness estimates are subject to possible modification. (F) Listed 50K sheets are those that include a portion of the entire Severn catchment. More work might be needed to decide if some rivers like the Teme (the valley of which includes pre-Devensian terraces related to the River Wye!)
column79: or indeed the Upper (later Devensian) Severn (see above) should be included.@en'

column54: and in eastern East Anglia also unconformably overlies the older glacigenic Happisburgh Formation (formerly Corton Formation on some maps) and the fluvial sands and gravels of the Dunwich Group. The tills within the Lowestoft Formation typically contain a significantly higher percentage of chalk than the underlying tills. The gravels in the Dunwich Group contain a significant amount of quartzose lithologies and only very minor quantities of erratics and chalk
column55: whereas the gravels in the Lowestoft Formation contain common erratics from Scotland and northern England
column56: and abundant chalk where not decalcified.@en'
column59: 'The Lowestoft Formation is overlain unconformably by deposits of the Britannia Catchments Group and in northeastern East Anglia by the Sheringham Cliffs Formation. Where the uppermost part of the Lowestoft Formation comprises sand and gravel
column60: it is not always easy to determine its upper boundary if overlain by younger sand and gravel
column61: but in general the younger sand and gravel is better sorted and chalk free.@en'
column70: 'The Lowestoft Formation forms an extensive sheet of chalky till
column71: together with outwash sands and gravels
column72: silts and clays. The till is characterised by its chalk and flint content. The carbonate content of the till matrix is about 30\%
column73: and tills within the underlying Happisburgh Formation have less than 20\%.@en'
column81: 'There is some debate as to the extent of the Lowestoft Formation. It is extensive over East Anglia having its southern limit near Romford
column82: Essex. It is probable that most of the chalky tills in central East Anglia are also part of the Lowestoft Formation. In northern East Anglia the very chalky tills commonly referred to informally as the "marly drift" were generally included within the Lowestoft Formation
column83: but recent work has indicated that these may belong to a younger glaciation. Likewise
column84: chalky tills in the south and east Midlands have commonly been linked with the Lowestoft Formation
column85: but these may also be younger. It is also uncertain how the pre-Devensian tills in Lincolnshire relate to the Lowestoft Formation.@en'
column87: 'Extremely variable. It is thickest in buried valleys where locally up to 60m may be present. Thick accumulations are also more generally present beneath much of northern Essex and south Suffolk.@en'
column95: 'Ground surface or unconformable contact with units of the Caledonia Glacigenic Group
column96: the Britannia Catchments Group or the British Coastal Deposits Group.@en'
column109: glaciolacustrine and glaciomarine deposits that contain clasts derived from rocks cropping out throughout northern
column120: planar unconformable contact with units of the Dunwich and/or Crag groups
column122: 'The whole of Great Britain lying to the north of the Anglian glacial limit crossing southern England
column123: but mainly occuring between the Anglian and Devension glacial limits.@en'
column141: 'Restricted to the valley sides of the River Waveney and Hundred River to the west and south of Lowestoft.@en;Restricted to the southwestern flanks of the Yare and Waveney valleys and isolated deposits on the northern flanks of the Waveney valley near Somerleyton
column142: Norfolk-Suffolk border.@en;Cliff sections between Corton Woods
column144: north Norfolk. The deposit has been traced westwards inland in a series of shallow boreholes for some 400m.@en;Found in outcrops throughout the North Walsham and Cromer districts; occurs in coastal sections between Happisburgh and Overstrand
column148: 'The Aldeby Sand and Gravel Member is lithogically very variable; it is composed predominantly of sand and gravel that also contains lenses of reworked chalky till
column149: discrete beds of clay and silt
column150: reconstituted chalk and masses of sand transported and apparently derived from the Happisburgh Formation. The gravel fraction is composed predominantly of clasts of angular flint with some quartz and quartzite. In places beds of well-rounded flint and quartz gravel are present. The Member is thought to have formed during wastage of the Lowestoft ice from the adjacent higher ground.@en;The Haddiscoe Sand and Gravel Member comprises black
column151: well-rounded fine to coarse flint gravel. Within the gravel large rotated blocks of sand are preserved
column152: which are thought to have been in a frozen condition at the time of deposition.@en;Composed of horizontally laminated pale grey sandy silts and grey clays with sporadic isolated pale grey sand lenses.@en;The lower boundary of the Walcott Till Member consists of an olive grey to olive brown silt-rich matrix-supported diamicton that is largely massive in structure. It has a moderate matrix calcium carbonate content of c.36\% and contains an abundance of chalk and flint clasts.@en'
column156: most commonly overlies silt- and clay-rich chalky till (diamicton) of the Lowestoft Formation
column157: but also locally overlies well-sorted sands and gravels of the Crag Group and Happisburgh Formation.@en;The gravels overlie and cut down into silt and clay-rich chalky tills of the Lowestoft Formation. They also overlie sands of the Happisburgh Formation.@en;The basal contact of the Oulton Clay Member with the underlying Lowestoft Till Member is sharp
column158: and represented by an abrupt transition from clay-rich till
column159: to laminated silts and clays.@en;The lower boundary of the Walcott Till Member is irregular and erosional and lies upon either sandy Wroxham Crag Formation sediments or on laminated silts and clays of the Happisburgh Glacigenic Formation. Commonly these underlying sediments exhibit evidence of shearing. [See also the Stratotype information.]@en'
column161: 'Aldeby Sand And Gravel Member@en;Haddiscoe Sand And Gravel Member@en;Oulton Clay Member@en;Walcott Till Member@en'
column165: 'Thicknesses are imprecisely known but 18m was exposed at Oaklands Pit
column167: (see Stratotypes).@en;Up to about 15m@en;Maximum thickness of 2.2m observed at stratotype.@en;A maximum of 2.2m has been observed.@en'
column168: 'The Aldeby Sand and Gravel is overlain unconformably by variable Head deposits
column169: and peat and silt of the Breydon Formation
column170: and locally by river terrace sand and gravel of the Britannia Catchments Group. The overlying sand and gravel is typically better sorted and more well bedded.@en;The Haddicoe Sand and Gravel Member is generally at the surface
column171: but is locally overlain in valleys by Head
column172: and on the lowermost ground by silt and peat of the Breydon Formation.@en;The upper contact of the Oulton Clay Member with the overlying Pleasure Gardens Till Member is diffuse and represented by the interdigitation of beds of silt and clay with lenses of chalky till.@en;The diamicton is generally overlain by the outwash sands of the Mundesley Sand Member. The junction between the two units is commonly sharp and erosional.@en'

column61: 'Comprises the pre-Devensian glacial succession of much of the English Midlands. Predominantly tills

column68: and flint-rich outwash gravels (Dunsmore Gravel Member). Characteristically lacks Scottish and Lake districts erratics (which characterise the Devensian Stockport Formation)

column72: '(A) The name follows Bowen et al (1999) and BGS provisional Framework document. (B) The consensus view in academia is that this unit is Stage 12 (as per Bowen 1999)
column73: but there is evidence to suggest it is younger Stage 10
column74: or both 10 and 12. (C) The succession within the Wolston Formation is only touched upon; neither the Wolston Clay Member nor the synonymous Grounds Farm Member are mentioned. (D) The precise limits of the Wolston Formation are contentious. It could be taken to the Devensian limit in Lincolnshire but Lewis (in Bowen
column75: 1999) excluded things such as the Wragby Till (putting it in the Lowestoft Formation)
column76: which could be included in the Wolston Formation. Thus the limit in the east is fairly arbitrary
column77: and the northern limit is particularly vague
column78: and probably best left as such until some primary work has been done on the older drifts of the south Pennines area. (E) As this unit is not actually distinguished on any BGS maps (locally its component members are) the listing of 50K sheets is actually superfluous
column79: but a list is included to show the areas where the Wolston Formation should encompass the glacial deposits.@en'
